Health_consequences:
(1) Drowning (accounts for 75% of deaths in flood disasters)
(2) Deaths from physical trauma, heart attacks, electrocution, carbon monoxide poisoning or fire associated with flooding
(3) Water- and vector-borne diseases, such as cholera, typhoid or malaria
(4) Injuries, such as lacerations or punctures from evacuations and disaster cleanup chemical hazards (5) Mental health effects associated with emergency situations (6) Disrupted health systems, facilities and services, leaving communities without access to health care (7) Damaged basic infrastructure, such as food and water supplies, and safe shelter  (8) Increased as gender-based violence or abuse and associated health consequencies of flood relief services and recovery
Geographical_Area: Central(Kapiri Mposh, Shibuyunji, Chibombo and Mumbwa districts),Copperbelt (Lufwanyama district),Eastern (Mambwe, Chama districts),Luapula (Lunga district),Lusaka (Lusaka, Kafue districts), Muchinga (Isoka, Chinsali , Mpika districts ),North Western (Zambezi, Chavuma district), Southern (Namwala, Monze, Itezhi Tezhi, Mazabuka, Chikankata districts),Western (Kalabo, Mitete) ,Northern(Chilubi district).
Exposure: An extimated total 200000 people are at risk of floods as follows: Central  4470 people (Kapiri Mposhi, Shibuyunji, Chibombo and Mumbwa rural districts),Copperbelt 8304 people (Lufwanyama rural district),Eastern 7411 (Mambwe, Chama rural districts),Luapula 2509 people (Lunga rural district),Lusaka 27884 people (Lusaka - urban, Kafue - peri-urban districts), Muchinga 9227 people (Isoka rural, Chinsali per-urban , Mpika peri-urban districts ),North Western 21482 people (Zambezi, Chavuma rural districts), Southern 101442 people (Namwala rural, Monze - rural, Itezhi Tezhi - rural, Mazabuka - peri urban, Chikankata rural districts),Western 17272 people(Kalabo, Mitete rural districts)
Vulnerability_Details: Population at risk include  the maginalized ( differently abled people, orphans, women, the aged, female headed households).  High number of unprotected water sources ( 82%  do not treat their water ), Practice open defeacation, high enteric disease conditions in children  (40%),  poor  solid waste management ( 71% use pity latrines) high malnutrition levels (35%) poor housing conditions, unemployed with no source of regular income.  (ZVAC 2020 and ZDHS 2018)
Governance_and_Resouces: • Contigency plan and in country financing • Functional EOC and multisectoral mechanism
Health_Sector_Capacity: • Event based surveillance and Lab network capacities  •Availabity of RRT and  health workforce capacitiies
Non_Health_Sector_Capcity: • Human resource relevant to emergency preparedness, response and recovery;limited flood adaptation capacity • Early warning systems  for hydro-meteorological; limited dissemination of early warning information
Commuty_Capacity: Low knowledge levels and poor practices as related to floods • Community perception and attitudes
Resources: • Inadequate mechanisms for logistics, storage and essential supplies • Structures available for supporting vulnerable populations and inadequate contigency funds

Health_consequences:
(1) Cutaneous: Cutaneous anthrax accounts for > 95% of human cases worldwide. The lesions (eschars) are generally found on exposed regions of the body almost invariably accompanied by marked oedema extending some distance from the lesion
(2) Oro-pharyngeal: Sore throat, dysphagia and regional lymphadenopathy are
the early clinical features associated with oropharyngeal anthrax, with development of extensive oedematous swelling of the neck and anterior chest wall. 
(3) Gatrointestinal: Symptoms of gastrointestinal anthrax are initially nonspecific and
include nausea, vomiting, anorexia, mild diarrhoea and fever. These may be mild but are occasionally severe, progressing to haematemesis, bloody diarrhoea and massive ascites.

Health_consequences:
(1) Early symptoms of a rabies infection can include a fever with pain and unusual or unexplained tingling, pricking or burning sensation (paraesthesia) at the wound site.
(2) Furious rabies causes signs of hyperactivity, excitable behaviour, hydrophobia (fear of water) and sometimes aerophobia (fear of drafts or of fresh air). Death occurs after a few days due to cardio-respiratory arrest. the case fatality rate for rabies is almost 100%
(3) Paralytic rabies runs a less dramatic and usually longer course than the furious form. Muscles gradually become paralysed, starting at the site of the bite or scratch. A coma slowly develops and eventually death occurs

Hazard: Acts of Violence (Bike riders, football hooliganism, domestic violence)
Health_consequences:
Large numbers of wounded - may overwhelm health workers
Disruption of health services delivery (e.g. health workers affected by violence/insecurity)
Supply chain disruption
Limited access to health facilities
Deaths
Psychosocial trauma
Geographical_Area: AnyArea
Vulnerability_Details:
• Minimally affected health services, violence is usually short lived and on a smaller scale, HF not at risk of violence
• Health Status of population at risk: young men [youth] aged (18-35) and some women;  many are prone to drug abuse
• Passerbys can be indirectly affected: street traders, destitute and mentally ill persons on the streets 
• Live in overcrowded conditions; mainly occurs in cities
Governance_and_Resouces: • Laws and policies are in place at national level and by-laws in communities; (policy in place for military aid to civil police); exercised and tested before. National and district plan/policy • Existing union for bike riders and motor drivers; (inclusive of Secretariat) •Available structures for law enforcement; Sierra Leone police provides security at football matches;  • Information sharing loose coordination (though splintered, not common table) ; separate planning for security and Ministry of Sports • For inter-school matches, Ministry of Basic Education is involved; Ministry of Internal Affairs (including police) • Ministry of Youth Affairs and Councils support to youths training for employment, livelihood;
Non_Health_Sector_Capcity: •Prevention: National Civic Education and Development; civic education on rights and responsibilities;  • Religious Institutions, (Inter-Religious Council) , mediation efforts and broker peace within groups
Commuty_Capacity:
• Social Media/community radios for communicating messages; awareness raising; communicate on the incident (real-time situation); WhatsApp and viral messaging
• Local chiefs to pacify situations
Resources: •Health HR: Trained health personnel in emergencies and response; existing emergency unit (national and district), Health Facilities;  • FInancial resources for movement of drugs/supply from national stock to district and community, free supplies for victims •National Commission for Social Action (safety net) NaCSA

Vulnerability_Details:
Mining Accidents (vulnerability); risk of open pitfalls: 

Artisanal and Professional Miners: Youth aged 18-35 (both male and female), but more male, unskilled artisanal miners (economic reasons, pursuing mining activities, low income)

Social Determinants: Mining population are mostly have low literacy and lower income, sex workers are present in the area, inclusive of young girls

Environmental: exposure to chemicals in water sources of whole of population; malaria prone-areas due to stagnant waters, sometimes food insecurity as traders do not want to be located in mining area (fear of falling into pits, malaria, chemical exposure)

Health_consequences:
(1) Early symptoms of a rabies infection can include a fever with pain and unusual or unexplained tingling, pricking or burning sensation (paraesthesia) at the wound site.
(2) Furious rabies causes signs of hyperactivity, excitable behaviour, hydrophobia (fear of water) and sometimes aerophobia (fear of drafts or of fresh air). Death occurs after a few days due to cardio-respiratory arrest. 
(3) Paralytic rabies runs a less dramatic and usually longer course than the furious form. Muscles gradually become paralysed, starting at the site of the bite or scratch. A coma slowly develops and eventually death occurs

Health_consequences:
(1) Cutaneous: Cutaneous anthrax accounts for > 95% of human cases worldwide. The lesions (eschars) are generally found on exposed regions of the body almost invariably accompanied by marked oedema extending some distance from the lesion
(2) Oro-pharyngeal: Sore throat, dysphagia and regional lymphadenopathy are
the early clinical features associated with oropharyngeal anthrax, with development of extensive oedematous swelling of the neck and anterior chest wall. 
(3) Gatrointestinal: Symptoms of gastrointestinal anthrax are initially nonspecific and include nausea, vomiting, anorexia, mild diarrhoea and fever. These may be mild but are occasionally severe, progressing to haematemesis, bloody diarrhoea and massive ascites.

Health_consequences:
(1) Burns, smoke inhalation, respiratory distress
(2) Prolonged hospitalization, disfigurement and disability, often with resulting stigma and rejection, death
(3) Damage to homes and infrastructure
(4) Economic losses
Geographical_Area: Western Area Urban (46000), Western Area Rural, Bo, Bonthe, Moyamba, Pujehun, Kenema, Kono, Kailahun, Tonlolili, Bomabali, Kambia, Koinadugu, Portloko, Karene, Falaba
Vulnerability_Details:
URBAN FIRE
• Inadequate functional capacity of hospitals for managing burn cases (Burn units/care centers)
• Health status of Population at risk: Co Morbid conditions  (Asthmatic people easily get into attacks because of smoke inhalation, Malnutrition causes weak immune response which delays healing processes and Alertness), No Specialized Burns treatment centers
• Social Determinants: Slums (High risk setting as in congested localities), Illiteracy (Lack of knowledge on fire safety), Poverty as in poor infrastructural choices (clustered structures, fire friendly building materials, etc, Lack of research and development system for operational research in fire emergencies, Good knowledge however, there is poor attitudes and practice about how to prevent and control fire outbreak, inadequare committment from partners on fire support
• Presence of vulnurable groups: Women and children are less active interms of disaster escape, , Persons with disability (Blind, Deaf and Dumb, Mental impairedness which slowers or restricts moverment in  times of fire)
• Environmental Factors: Poor sanitation for households are been used as a storage space for irrelevant materials which exercerbates fire, Overcrowding leads to congestion and limits escape, Improperly managed wastes causes easy fire enrouting, Civil unrest as in gangstarism causes unlawful fire placements when emotions spike
 WILD FIRE
• Social Determinants: poor infrastructure ( Thatch roofs, Dried tree bamboo houses)  
• Presence of vulnurable groups: Plantation farms are lost anytime there is fire outtage, 
• Environmental Factors: Grassland communities forms an unintentional fuel source whenever there is fire outtage,
inadequate drugs and medical supplies for the management of burns
•
Coping_capacity_details:
Governance (National and Districts)
• Existence of partners coordination,
• Existing Govt. Institutions that responds to fire incidents (NDMA and National fireforce)
Health Sector Capacities (National and Districts)
• Stable supply chain management systems 
Medical staff were trained for Fire management,
Non-health Sector Capacities (District and National) 
• Existing disaster response coordination but private sector capacity for support to health emergencies and disasters should be scaled up
Community
 Existence of community faith based groups that supports fire response
Resources
• Both financial and logistic resources are limited to manage fire outbreak

(4) Injuries, such as lacerations or punctures from evacuations and disaster cleanup 
chemical hazards
(5) Mental health effects associated with emergency situations
(6) Disrupted health systems, facilities and services, leaving communities without access to health care 
(7) Damaged basic infrastructure, such as food and water supplies, and safe shelter.

Vulnerability_Details:
• Health status of Population at risk; innadequate drugs and medical supplies for the management of Mudslide victims and all age groups and gender are affected 
inadequate functional capacity of hospitals for managing Mudslide victims

•Social Determinants; private sector capacity for support to health emergencies and disasters should be scaled up, high risk group (muddy mountanous areas), Non specific (All affected),
 
• Presence of vulnurable groups; Non Specific 

• Environmental Factors; High precipitation, Deforestation, Poor housing and planning
Coping_capacity_details:
Governance
• Compliance and enforcement of House planning very low
• Existing multi sectoral coordination mechanism at national and District Level (NDMA, PHNEOC, DEOC, DDMC, One Health Platform) 

Health Sector Capacities
• Lack of Emergency medical centers for managing mass casualties from mudslide 
• Existing Surveillance and early warning system 
• Stable supply chain management systems 

Non-health Sector Capacities
• Existing disaster response coordination 
• Existing mechanisms to seek for surge for disatster response (Internal and external-PDP)

Community
• people in the community are Very knowledgeable however, there is poor attitudes and practices of house planning regulations
Resources
• Both financial and logistic resources are limited to manage mud slide outbreak

Health_consequences:
(1) Affections respiratoires pouvant être grave: desaturation avec detresse respiratoire, mort subite
(2) Besoins accrus de santé mentale et de psycho-soutien,
(3) Perturbations socio-économiques, y compris la perte de revenu familial
(4) Perturbation du système de santé: relachement des activités de routine (vaccinations de routine, PF, surveillance des autres maladies, et prise en charge des autres maladies en général); surcharge des services hospitaliers (y compris les admissions, perturbations de la prise en charge des maladies chroniques, ruptures en intrants dûs à la perturbation des trafics internationaux), Agents de santé submergés et affectés par la COVID jusqu'au décès.
(5) Post Covid-19: Habituellement 3 mois à compter du début de Covid-19 avec des symptômes qui durent au moins 2 mois et ne peuvent pas être expliqués par un diagnostic alternatif. Les symptômes courants comprennent la fatigue, l'essoufflement, céphalée chronique, myalgie chronique, le dysfonctionnement cognitif (surtout perte de mémoire mais également d'autres) et ont généralement un impact sur le fonctionnement quotidien donc la production et à long termes la malnutrition chronique.
Geographical_Area: Alarotra mangoro,Amoron'i Mania,Analamanga,Analanjirofo,Androy,Anosy,Atsinanana,Betsiboka,Boeni,Bongolava,Diane,Haute-Matsiatra,Ihorombe,Itasy,Mélange,Menabé,Sava,Sofia,Sud-Est,Sud-Ouest,Vakinankaratra,VatovaVy FitoVinany
Exposure: Population totale en général: 29 036 222
Vulnerability_Details:
•Comportements de la population (Gestes barrières Lowment respectées, réligion, ignorance, déni de la maladie)
•Low couverture vaccinale anti COVID 19
•Comorbidité (HTA, Diabète, maladies de surcharges)
•Age (Principalement les personnes agées)
•Plateau technique insuffisant (en Ressources Humaines_qualité et quantité, en matériels et équipements, infrastructures, intrants et consommables). Système de Fonds de prévoyance pour les urgences  non encore en place.
Coping_capacity_details:
Workforce / Finance / Fourniture:
•Approche multisectorielle, Structure de coordination unique et dédiée avec déclinaison régionale (Centre de Commandement Opérationnel_CCO);
•Appui des PTF
Système de santé:
•Augmentation de la capacité d'acceuil (Logistiques, Ressources humaines); Système de surveillance fonctionnel jusqu'au niveau communautaire; Ressources humaines formées, exercées et équipées; Capacité de détection/diagnostic et de prévention: mise en place de laboratoires spécialisés au niveau national et régional; Etablissements de soins de santé éxistants à tous les niveaux du système de santé; Etablissements  de soins dédiés; Agents communautaires dynamiques; Approche coup de poing; COUSP existant jusqu'au niveau régional, EIR disponibles.
•Intrants disponibles
Communauté:
•Mécanisme de mobilisation des autorités politiques, administratives, réligieuses et traditionnelles (APART) existe; Cartographie et renforcements des capacités à tous les points effectués.
•Matériels et stratégies spécifiques de sensibilisation et d'éducation de la communauté
Plan d'urgence:
•Plan multisectoriel d'urgence COVID; Plan de contingence COVID, Plan de communication spécifique
•Cartographie des points d'entrées et des zones à risques connues (source: DVSSER/ CVSF)
Les autres:
• Dispositif de contrôle au niveau des points d'entrée: caméra thérmique, POS de contrôle sanitaire aux frontières sur les maladies à potentiel épidémique

Vulnerability_Details:
• Comportements et activités à risque: Non respect des bonnes pratiques d'hygiène alimentaire
• Conditions socio-economiques défavorables: Etablissements alimentaires insalubres
• Accès à l'eau potable limité (27,7% RGPH 3)
• Commercialisation des aliments périmés
• Insuffisance de système de contrôle: Inspecteurs d'hygiène en nombre insuffisant; 3 laboratoires pour tout Madagascar (tous situés à Antananarivo); Non application des dispositions réglementaires en vigueur (Obligation de disposer d'Arrêté communal sur la vente des aliments pour toutes les communes; Non application des sanctions); Ressources financières limitées de la structure de contrôle (Agence de Contrôle de la Sécurité et de la Qualité des Denrées Alimentaires); Un seul centre antipoison pour Madagascar (au sein Réanimation Médicale du CHUJRA)
Coping_capacity_details:
Workforce / Finance / Fourniture:
• Collaboration multisectorielle existante pour le contrôle de la sécurité sanitaire des aliments (Ministère de la santé, Ministère en charge du commerce, La douane, Institut National des Sciences et Techniques Nucléaires_INSTN, Centre National de Recherches en Environnement_CNRE); Collaboration avec les collectivités territoriales décentralisées; Collaboration entre DVSSER et ACSQDA
• Loi régissant la sécurité des denrées alimentaires et de l'alimentation animale  
Système de santé:
• Existence de structure au  niveau ministère: ACSQDA
• Surveillance jusqu'au niveau communautaire de la TIAC fait partie de la SIMR (Surveillance Intégrée des Maladies et Riposte)
Communauté:
• Implication effective des agents communautaires dans la riposte (Guide PAC_paquet d'activités spécifiques)
•
Plan d'urgence:
• Procédures Opérationnelles Standards (POS)
• Plan stratégique national

-Conséquences immédiates : douleurs articulaires souvent invalidantes pendant des semaines. La mortalité concerne surtout les personnes âgées avec des comorbidités

-Conséquences secondaires : douleurs articulaires peuvent se prolonger des mois, voire des années; séquelles neurologiques prolongées

Health_consequences:
CD
(1) Noyade
(2) décès (au moins 0.001% de la population environ 206 personnes sont décédés pour la saison 2021_2022)
(3) environ 302 000 personnes sont affectées par des maladies d’origine hydrique et de vecteur, telles que le choléra, la typhoïde ou le paludisme, etc 
(3) Au niveau national, au moins 812 000 personnes sont affectées par l’IRA, dont environ 632 018 pour les 16 régions exposées par l’inondation.
(3) Au niveau national, environ 1  760 000 personnes sont affectées par le paludisme dont 1 417 173 pour les 16 régions exposées par l’inondation.
(4) Blessures
(5) Les systèmes de santé, les installations et les services perturbés, laissant des communautés sans accès aux soins de santé ( au moins 30 à 35% de la population soit  20 000 ménages n’ont pas accès aux services de santé ),
(6) Infrastructure de base endommagée, telle que la nourriture et les approvisionnements en eau et un abri sûr.
(7) Au niveau national, au moins 302 038 personnes sont affectées par la diarrhée, dont environ 201 481 pour les 16 régions exposées par l’inondation.
Geographical_Area:
16 Régions/ 23
SAVA, DIANA, MELAKY, BOENY, SOFIA, MENABE, ATSIMO ANDRAFANA, ATSIMO ATSINANA, FITOVINANY, HAUTE MATSIATRA, IHOROMBE, VATOVAVY, ATSINANANA, ANALANJIROFO, ANALAMANGA, ALAOTRA MANGORO
Vulnerability_Details:
Facteur de vulnérabilité communautaires
o Facteurs physiques : Précarité de l’état de santé, maladie (Diarrhée, paludisme, IRA), installation de la population dans les zones inondables, 
o Facteurs socio-économiques : taux d’alphabétisation Low (homme = 37.8%, femme = 35.8%), taux de pauvreté élevé (81%), 
o Facteurs environnementaux : système de drainage défaillant
 Vulnérabilité du système de santé 
o Accessibilité limité au système de santé
o Insuffisance de formation sanitaire de référence (CHDR, CHRD, CHR)
o Insuffisance de personnel de la santé (1/5000 alors que la norme est de 1/500)
Coping_capacity_details:
Capacité d’adaptation générique
o Fort leadership 
o Existence du COUSP (centre opérationnel d’urgence de santé publique dont le siège est à la DVSSER)
o Existence du plan d’intervention
o Soutien opérationnel et logistique disponible
o Population sensibilisée 
• Capacité d’adaptation spécifique :
o Existence du SURECA (service des urgences et des ripostes aux épidémies et aux catastrophes), SEMI (service d'équipe mobile d'intervention), dans toutes les régions
o Existence du plan spécifique d’intervention 
o Existence du système de surveillance dédié
o Existence du logistique médical
o Disponibilité des matériels et stratégies de sensibilisation et d’éducation
o Disponibilité de personnel de santé
o Existence des partenaires techniques et financiers locaux
o Existence des ONG 
o Existence du BNGRC (bureau national de gestion des risques et catastrophes), y compris le CERVO (centre d’étude de réflexion de veille et orientation) et la direction des opérations en charge des réponses aux urgences et catastrophes
o Existence de la CPGU (cellule de prévention et gestion des urgences)

CD

Health_consequences:
CD
(1) Malnutrition (y compris la carence en micronutriments et l'anémie de carence en oligoéléments) et mortalité
(2) Insécurité alimentaire et eau
(3) Risque accru de maladies infectieuses Épidémies et des maladies liées à l'eau (choléra, diarrhée et pneumonie) et décès dû à la malnutrition, au manque de lavage et de déplacement
(4) Diminution du pouvoir d'achat des ménages et de la perturbation potentielle des services de santé
(5) Troubles accrus de stress et de santé mentale
(6) Risque supplémentaire pour les personnes touchées par les maladies pulmonaires, l'asthme ou les maladies chroniques (cœur, respiratoire)
(7) Migration de la population, forcée de quitter les zones locales
(8) Dilapidation des actifs et des moyens d'existence réduisant l'accès aux services de santé (accès économique, accès physique)
(9) Stratégies d'adaptation négative et de survie pouvant porter atteinte à l'intégrité physique
(10)  Au niveau national, au moins 812 000 personnes sont affectées par l’IRA, dont environ 53 485 pour les 3 régions exposées par la sècheresse.
(11) Au niveau national, au moins 302 038 personnes sont affectées par la diarrhée, dont environ 22 397 pour les 3 régions exposées par la sècheresse.
(12) Au niveau national, environ 1  760 000 personnes sont affectées par le paludisme dont 328 374 pour les 3 régions exposées par la sècheresse

Hazard: Transportation accidents (RTA, Boat or Ferry capsize, air crash, maritime)
Health_consequences: Conséquences immediats: impact physique( décès, noyade, blessures, traumatisme, infirmité, invalidité/ incapacit), impact psychologique( psychose post traumatique), perturbation du systèmes de santé par l'inadequation du moyen disponible et le nombre de victime
Geographical_Area: tout le pays
Exposure:
1. Circulation aerinene:  2000 passagers exposés par jours,   0-86 personnes exposés victmes d'ecrasément,  0-20 personnes sauveteurs exposés par jours.                                                                                            
2. Circulation routiere: environ 7 millions personnes exposés par jours ( passagers, population environnante)                                                                                                                                          
3. Circulation maritime: 133 equipages exposés par jours, 693 passagers exposés par jours, 0-10 personnes sauveteurs exposés par jours
Vulnerability_Details:
SYSTEME DE SANTE
-	Inaccessibilité/éloignement des formations sanitaires pour le recours aux soins
-	Dépourvu des formations sanitaires
-	Système de secours d’urgence/ Kits de soins d’urgence gratuite à échelle réduite, équipe médicale d’urgence non fonctionnelle
-	Couverture sanitaire universelle limitée au district pilote (Vatomandry)
-	Sécurité sociale des pêcheurs en cours de mise en place (Ministère du travail)
-	Evacuation sanitaire : non gratuite, inexistante
RESSOURCES (humaine, matérielle, financière)
-	Personnel de santé insuffisant (généraliste, urgentiste, secouriste, réanimateurs, ambulanciers, …
-	Matériels, infrastructures non disponibles et/ou insuffisants et/ou défectueux
-	Poste sanitaire mobile non disponible
CAPACITE D'ADAPTATION
-	Low leadership, coordination et centre des opérations d’urgence (surtout préparation et briefing)
-	Plan d’intervention et législation en place : ORSEC existante mais non spécifique pour accident de transport
-	Fonds de prévoyance pour les urgences : aérienne, maritime et terrestre Low
-	Equipements médicaux d’urgences :
•	plateau technique et personnels au niveau ex provinciaux insuffisant, kits d’urgence au niveau hospitalier  insuffisant
•	Transport routier : extincteur  non fonctionnel, kit d’urgence non disponible/inadéquat
-	Capacité de détection/diagnostic et de prévention en toute sécurité : 
•	transport routier non fiable (voiture passant aux visites techniques mais non fiable)
-	Soutien opérationnel et logistique : SURECa et points focaux non spécifique aux accidents de transports
-	Sensibilisation du public et engagement communautaire :
	Transport fluviale et maritime côtière : 
•	Equipement de protection individuel, consigne de sécurité inexistant 
-	Cartographie et renforcement des capacités à tous les points :
	Transport routier : 
•	Cartographie des zones accidentogènes et renforcement des capacités en matière de secourisme/premier soins à tous les points inexistants
Coping_capacity_details:
_	Plan d’intervention et législation en place : ORSEC existante 
-	Fonds de prévoyance pour les urgences : aérienne, maritime et terrestre existent 
-	Système de surveillance : pour transport aérien et maritime, brigade de sécurité routière, police urbaine existant et fonctionnel
-	Ressources humaines formées, exercées et équipées
-	Exercice de simulation et retour d’expérience (RETEX, SIMEX) spécifiques sur transport aérien, routier, maritime et fluviale existante régulièrement
-	Equipements médicaux d’urgences :
•	pour transport aérien et maritime disponible
•	plateau technique et personnels au niveau ex provinciaux existant , kits d’urgence au niveau hospitalier disponible
•	Transport routier : extincteur disponible , 
-	Capacité de détection/diagnostic et de prévention en toute sécurité : 
•	avion (contrôle, visite avant départ), maritime, météorologie  
-	Etablissement de soins de santé adéquat : CHU, CHRR, CHRD, CSB, DCAMUM
-	Soutien opérationnel et logistique : SURECa et points focaux fonctionnels 
-	Sensibilisation du public et engagement communautaire :
	Transport routier :
•	Sensibilisation médiatique intense à chaque festivité
•	Sensibilisation de routine, panneaux de signalisation existant
	Transport aérien et pour les grands navires :
•	Equipement de protection individuelle existant
•	Consigne de sécurité existant
-	Cartographie et renforcement des capacités à tous les points :
	Transport aérien et maritime :
•	Cartographie des zones accidentogènes et renforcement des capacités en matière de secourisme/premier soins à tous les points existants

Health_consequences:
(1) Décès, Blessures, traumatisme, invalidité physique, (2) trouble psychologique,  grossesse non desiré, sterilité, IST, sequelles gyneco-obstétricaux
conséquence secondaire: besoin accru de santé mentale et de soutien psycho-social
Le nombre croissant de civils, y compris des femmes et des enfants, a été tué, blessé, traité sans dignité, détenu arbitrairement détenu et / ou séparé de leur famille, abusé sexuel, exposé à la faim et placé à risque accru d'infections
 Dommages  infrastructures sanitaires et fermeture même
 perturbation du système de santé,  abandon de poste  et refus de poste d'affectation des personnels de santé

•	Plateau technique et personnels au niveau ex provinciaux existant , kits d’urgence au niveau hospitalier disponible 
-	Disponibilité des ambulances mobilisable (commune, hôpitaux, DCAMUM, DVSSER)

Health_consequences:
(1) conséquences immédiates : intoxications, apparition d'allergies, atteintes des organes (appareil respiratoire, système digestif, peau et muqueuse), décès

(2) conséquences secondaires : affaiblissement du système immunitaire, cancer (sang, foie, testicule, sein), problème de fertilité, anomalie congénitale, effets sur le développement mental, cognitif ou physique de l'enfant, troubles du système cariovasculaire, effets mutagènes (perturbation endocrinienne), décès

(3) pertubation du système de santé (non-disponibilité des antidotes de façon permanente, )

Exposure:
(1) Groupes de population exposée : Plus de 80% de la population notamment la Population vivant près des décharges sauvages/mines/industries, Travailleurs, Agriculteurs et leurs familles, Personnel de santé (agents pulvérisateurs, laborantins, personnel dans les services radiologies), Consommateurs 

(2) Nombre de population totale exposée : 22 191 150
Vulnerability_Details:
• Facteurs physiques : personnes vivant avec des tares, personnes immunodeficientes, femmes, femmes enceintes, enfants, agents de santé, mésusage des pesticides, non port des EPI, 
• Facteurs socio-économiques : alphabétisation, travailleurs (agriculture, industrie, mine, santé, ...), chiffoniers, manque de budget de l'Etat alloué à la gestion sectorielle des produits chimiques, corruption (douane)
• Facteurs environnementaux : lacunes des réglementations des produits chimiques, non application de la loi, problème d'assainissement et gestion des déchets chimiques, caractères persistants des produits chimiques dans l'environnement, proximité des établissements industriels/décharges/mines à risque, insécurité alimentaire, insuffisance des matériels et équipements de laboratoire pour la détection de certains produits chimiques
• Vulnérabilité du système de santé : inexistence de centre antipoison, absence d'assurance santé, accessibilité limitée aux soins médicaux (disponibilité antidotes, ), insuffisance de sensbilisation sur les risques liés à l'utilisation ou exposition aux produits chimiques, insuffisance de personnel formés en matière de toxicologie/écotoxicologie/gestion des produits et déchets chimiques, insuffisance des capacités des laboratoires
Coping_capacity_details:
Workforce / Finance / Fourniture:
• Collaboration effective entre les Ministères en charge de la santé et de l'environnement, existence des cellules environnementales sectorielles mobilisables pour des activités de gestion d'urgence chimique, comités intersectoriels de mise en oeuvre du décret MECIE fonctionnels (ONE et tous les secteurs), Volet risque chimique intégré dans le Plan d'Action National de Sécurité Sanitaire
• Existence de ressources humaines (urgentistes, réanimateurs)
Système de santé:
• Existence d'établissements de santé à tous les niveaux
• Existence de système de surveillance effectif (DVSSER), évaluation de la conformité sanitaire des produits chimiques utilisés par les sociétés utilisant les produits chimiques (SSEnv)
Communauté:
• Existence d'acteurs communautaires

Plan d'urgence:
• existence de soutien opérationnel et logistique (BNGRC/SURECa), existence de COUSP à tous les niveaux, POS sur la gestion accidents chimiques en cours d'élaboration
Les autres:
• Existence de cadres juridiques sur les produits chimiques, existence du projet d'Observatoire national sur les produits chimiques (ChemObs), existence de documents de référence sur les produits chimiques (cartographie des risques, évaluation de la vulnérabilité, coût de l'inaction), existence de personnes ressources formées sur la détection des produits chimiques au niveau du Centre National de Recherche sur l'Environnement

Health_consequences:
(1) conséquences immédiates: maladies respiratoires, allergies, détresse respiratoire

(2) conséquences secondaires : cancer (poumons, peau), troubles cardiovasculaires, trouble de développement mental des enfants,décès

Health_consequences:
(1) Fever, cough, anosmia, ageusia, shortness of breath, weakness, respiratory distress, organ damage, 
(2)Increased needs for mental health and psycho-support,
(3) Socio-economic disruptions, including loss of family income 
(4) Disruption of health system, including routine immunizations, increased demand of hospital services (including admissions + ICU), etc.
(5) Post COVID-19 condition: usually 3 months from the onset of COVID-19 with symptoms that last for at least 2 months and cannot be explained by an alternative diagnosis. Common symptoms include fatigue, shortness of breath, cognitive dysfunction but also others and generally have an impact on everyday functioning.

Health_consequences:
(1) Cutaneous: Cutaneous anthrax accounts for > 95% of human cases worldwide. The lesions (eschars) are generally found on exposed regions of the body almost invariably accompanied by marked oedema extending some distance from the lesion
(2) Oro-pharyngeal: Sore throat, dysphagia and regional lymphadenopathy are
the early clinical features associated with oropharyngeal anthrax, with development of extensive oedematous swelling of the neck and anterior chest wall. 
(3) Gatrointestinal: Symptoms of gastrointestinal anthrax are initially nonspecific and
include nausea, vomiting, anorexia, mild diarrhoea and fever. These may be mild but are occasionally severe, progressing to haematemesis, bloody diarrhoea and massive ascites.
(4)  Septcemia, death
(5) Distruption of health system, social ecomic losses,

Health_consequences:
(1) Initially fever, fatigue, muscle, pain, headache, and sore throat. 
(2) This is followed by vomiting, diarrhea, rash, symptoms of impaired kidney and liver function, and in some cases internal and external bleeding (e.g. oozing from the gums, blood in the stools)
(3) Increased socio-economic disruptions
(4) Increased burden on the health system
(5) The average EVD case fatality rate is around 50%. Case fatality rates have varied from 25% to 90% in past outbreaks.

Health_consequences:
Immediate health consequences: 
(1) Drowning (accounts for 75% of deaths in flood disasters)
(2) Loss of life - Deaths from physical trauma, heart attacks, electrocution, carbon monoxide poisoning or fire associated with flooding
(3) Injuries, such as lacerations or punctures from evacuations and disaster cleanup 
chemical hazards

Medium- to long-term health consequences:
(4) Forced Displacement, leading to overcrowded shelters and the spread of communicable diseases and cases of GBV due to close proximity/crowded shelters 
(5) Loss of livelihood and negative socio-economic impacts, resulting in difficulties accessing health facilities and food insecurity (possible malnutrition)
(6) Water- and vector-borne diseases, such as cholera, typhoid or malaria
(7) Mental health effects associated with emergency situations

Health system consequences:
(8) Disrupted health systems, facilities and services, (EMS, PHC, Hospitals, Mortuaries) leaving communities without access to health care. Lack of access to primary health care services (including access to immunisation, chronic medication, health promotion, community health services are disrupted, burn-out of HCW and resulting union involvement disrupting health services)
(9) Strained/insufficient capacity of health systems, facilities and services (EMS, PHC, Hospitals, Mortuaries) - capacity of health workers, beds, equipment, medication, PPE, food etc. 
(9) Damaged basic infrastructures, such as food and water supplies, electricity supply.
Geographical_Area: Eastern Cape,Free State,Gauteng,Kwazulu-Natal,Limpopo,Mpumalanga,North West,Northern Cape,Western Cape
Exposure:
- 13,6% in informal dwellings, and 5,5% in traditional dwellings (StatsSA, 2017) - Approx. 19,1% of the population, which is approx. 11,48 million people
- # of communities living below a floodline – reach out to municipalities to get this
Vulnerability_Details:
Individual vulnerabilities - Health status of the population at risk:
• Vulnerable ages: elderly and under 5

Community vulnerabilities - Social determinants of health & vulnerable groups: 
• Compromised levels of literacy & education (communication/warning systems might not get to people, understanding of the risks in living in flood plains) 
• High levels of poverty & inequality resulting in livelihood crisis
• Population growth and population density
• Populations in Informal settlements / poor housing conditions (informal settlements tend to be developed rapidly and rapid, unplanned)
• Population living in Traditional Dwellings 
• Population living on the flood plains/low-lying areas
• Living close to areas where malaria vectors and other water-borne vectors are present
• Lack of critical infrastructure (water, sanitation, electricity, etc.), existing infrastructure can easily be destroyed or contaminated

Health system vulnerabilities – Environmental, governance & leadership:
• Inadequate air assets - Inability to reach patients and Lack of health aeromedical services to reach patients
• Delayed ICU availability
• Shortage of health specialist capacity (including advanced life support, nursing, and rehabilitation) limited to urban areas
• Insufficient scope of health promotion – training needs to be improved 
• Bed bureau only available in Gauteng and Western Cape (not at national level) 
• Poorly maintained and aging infrastructure (roof leaks, water damage, broken roofs etc.)
• Infrequent/insufficient trainings/education on floods for HCW 
• Staff wellness not prioritised – inadequate staff rotation 

• Compromised systems of good health governance & organisational systems
• Poor performance of lower-level health and inter-governmental structures
• Lack of enforcements that ensure people do not build in flood plains – intergovernmental relations need to be strengthened and health needs to be prioritised 
• Insufficient dissemination of information shared by early warning systems
•Insufficient information & data on hazards & vulnerabilities
• Compromised information sharing and reporting – Data-rich information poor

Non-health vulnerabilities: 
•Unemployment and low-income levels – the purchasing power of communities is reduced creating increased vulnerabilities
• Poor environmental & resource management
• Increased environment & resource degradation & overconsumption (natural resource crises)
•Human environmental damage: pollution, poor sanitation & waste management – environmental health practitioners
•Increased extreme weather events resulting in higher frequency & severity of hazards
• Insufficient maintenance of critical infrastructure (e.g. not cleaning storm water drains)
Coping_capacity_details:
Governance:
• Existing governance structures and communication strategies are in place to activate resources needed e.g. through NDMC, NATJOINTS, IMC, DJOC, ProvJOC
• Contingency Plans, e.g. business continuity plans for floods
• Emergency SOPs
• Debriefing and lessons learnt is a weakness
• Triaging system supports the access to care at a faster rate

Health Sector: 
• There are sufficient health governance coping capacities at national, provincial and local levels
• There is sufficient health infrastructure and systems to respond 
• Rapid response teams 
• Simulation exercises
• Emergency Medical Services capacity 
• Casualty capacity (incl. sufficient HCWs) 
• Primary healthcare capacity – water-borne diseases & injuries 
• Mortuary capacities
• Hospital capacity – ICU, paediatric wards 
• Forensic pathology services 
• Partnerships with the private sector 

Non-health Sector: 
• All government sectors come together to respond to a health emergency including water, agriculture, education, communication etc. There is thus capacity in the non-health sector
• Multi sectoral teams 

Community capacities 
• Civil organisations, and religious organisations have capacity to support communities to health emergencies
• NPO and NGOs (e.g. gift of the givers) support 
• Presence and active engagement of NGOs e.g. churches, civil rights groups etc. 

Resources
• There are financial resources to respond to health emergencies
•There are human resources present that can support the response to  health emergencies 
• availability of PPE 
• Logistics, 
• Disaster relief funds
• Transportation 
• IT health infrastructure
• Early warning systems for floods
• EMS Ambulances
• Helicopters through multisectoral collaborations 
• Partnering with private companies to gain access to air vehicles to support the response
• Financing – when a disaster is declared, resources are made available

Health_consequences:
Immediate health consequences:
(1) Heat illnesses (dehydration, swelling of lower limbs, heat rash, lethargy, weakness, heat exhaustion, heat stroke, convulsions etc),
(2) Multi-organ failure, coma, death
(3) Exacerbation of chronic medical conditions causing severe dehydration 
(4) Increased health burden impacting vulnerable population groups to a greater extent. 

Health system consequences:
(5) Increased burden on health and emergency services, increased strain on water and power supply, food insecurity
(6) Staff wellness disrupting health service delivery
(7) limited access to health services, heat potential to disrupt infrastructure
Geographical_Area: Free State,Gauteng,Limpopo,Mpumalanga,North West,Northern Cape,Western Cape
Exposure:
Farm laborer's (700 000 farm laborer's nationally). 
General population 60+, under 5: Ehlanzeni 387312, Mangaung 178486, Vhembe 311275, GTG 57899, West Coast 87046, Winelands 179938, Central Karoo 18104, Gauteng 2868456
Vulnerability_Details:
Individual vulnerabilities - Health status of the population at risk:
• Persons with compromised immunity 
• Vulnerable ages: elderly and under 5
• Presence of chronic medical conditions 

Community vulnerabilities - Social determinants of health & vulnerable groups: 
• Compromised levels of literacy & education
• High levels of poverty & inequality resulting in livelihood crisis
• Population growth and population density
• Transient populations 
• Informal populations 

Health system vulnerabilities – Environmental, governance & leadership:
• Accessibility of facilities and EMS vehicles in areas prone particularly in rural areas that are prone to heat waves 
• EMS response times can be long, number of ambulances, personal, systems to identify where the incidences are happening and adjusting the processes to improve the response

Health_consequences:
Immediate Heakth Consequences
(1) Burns and injuries, deaths
(2) Eye, nose, throat and lung irritation
(3) Decreased lung function, including coughing and wheezing
(4) Pulmonary inflammation, bronchitis, exacerbations of asthma, and other lung diseases
(5) Exacerbation of chronic diseases including asthma, TB, and cardiovascular diseases, such as heart failure

Secondary Health Conditions:
(6) Resulting air pollution can cause a range of health issues, including respiratory and cardiovascular problems.
(7) Mental health consequences from experiencing a health disaster
(8) disfigurement and disability, often with resulting stigma and rejection

Health system consequences: 
(9) Disruption of health services, due to restricted access (impacting access patient access, EMS access, health commodities reaching facilities, e.g. Oxygen, Patient food, 
(10) Destruction of health facilities (facilities in close proximity to wildfires)
(11) Increased burden on healthcare facilities 
(12) Prolonged hospitalization
(13) Damage to homes and infrastructure
(14) Economic losses, loss of livelihoods

chemical hazards

Immediate Health Consequences: 
(1) Acute illness: dehydration, heat illnesses, heatstroke
(2) Malnutrition (including micronutrient deficiency and iron-deficiency anaemia), impact of malnutrition on natural immunity, exacerbating infections and illnesses
(3) Food and water insecurity

Secondary Health Consequences: 
(4) Increased risk of infectious diseases outbreaks (cholera, diarrhoea and pneumonia) and death due to malnutrition, lack of WASH and displacement
(5) Decrease of Household buying power and potential disruption of health services
(6) Increased stress and mental health disorders, exacebated by economic loss (e.g. farming)
(7) Further risk to those impacted by lung diseases, asthma or chronic diseases (heart, respiratory), 
(8) Migration of population, forced to leave local areas

Health System Consequences:
(9) Disruption to health services due to restricted water access

Health_consequences:
(1) Fever, cough, anosmia, ageusia, shortness of breath, weakness, respiratory distress, organ damage, 
(2)Increased needs for mental health and psycho-support,
(3) Socio-economic disruptions, including loss of family income 
(4) Disruption of health system, including routine immunizations, increased demand of hospital services (including admissions + ICU), etc.
(5) Post COVID-19 condition: usually 3 months from the onset of COVID-19 with symptoms that last for at least 2 months and cannot be explained by an alternative diagnosis. Common symptoms include fatigue, shortness of breath, cognitive dysfunction but also others and generally have an impact on everyday functioning. (6) Impact on HCW - workforce, illness

Hazard: Influenza A - emergence of novel strain
Health_consequences:
(1) Sudden onset of fever, cough (usually dry), headache, muscle and joint pain, severe malaise (feeling unwell), sore throat and a runny nose.
(2) Severe illness or death occur especially in people at high risk, such as pregnant women, children under 59 months, and the elderly. 
(3) Health care workers are at high risk acquiring influenza virus infection due to increased exposure to the patients and risk further spread particularly to vulnerable individuals.
(4) Hospitalisation due to seasonal influenza leads to losses in working days due to sickness, reduction in quality of life due to secondary infections, increased school absenteeism and increased use of hospital resources
(5) Socio-economic losses

Health_consequences:
(1) Early symptoms of a rabies infection can include a fever with pain and unusual or unexplained tingling, pricking or burning sensation (paraesthesia) at the wound site.
(2) Furious rabies causes signs of hyperactivity, excitable behaviour, hydrophobia (fear of water) and sometimes aerophobia (fear of drafts or of fresh air). Death occurs after a few days due to cardio-respiratory arrest. 
(3) Paralytic rabies runs a less dramatic and usually longer course than the furious form. Muscles gradually become paralysed, starting at the site of the bite or scratch. A coma slowly develops and eventually death occurs

Health_consequences:
(1) Cutaneous: Cutaneous anthrax accounts for > 95% of human cases worldwide. The lesions (eschars) are generally found on exposed regions of the body almost invariably accompanied by marked oedema extending some distance from the lesion; 20% mortality without antibiotics
(2) Oro-pharyngeal: Sore throat, dysphagia and regional lymphadenopathy are
the early clinical features associated with oropharyngeal anthrax, with development of extensive oedematous swelling of the neck and anterior chest wall. Up to 90% mortality without treatment. 
(3) Gatrointestinal: Symptoms of gastrointestinal anthrax are initially nonspecific and
include nausea, vomiting, anorexia, mild diarrhoea and fever. These may be mild but are occasionally severe, progressing to haematemesis, bloody diarrhoea and massive ascites. 25-75% mortality. (4) Economic - animal health is affected; bans on import/export (5) Social - workforce (6) Bioterrorism risk

Vulnerability_Details:
Individual vulnerabilities - Health status of the population at risk:
• Vulnerable ages: elderly and under 5
• Presence of chronic medical conditions and underlying respiratory conditions Community vulnerabilities - Social determinants of health & vulnerable groups: 
• Compromised levels of literacy & education
• High levels of poverty & inequality resulting in livelihood crisis
• Population growth and population density
• Informal settlement populations 
• Farming communities Health system vulnerabilities:
• Rapid, unplanned urbanisation (informal settlements) 
• Fragile & dangerous physical environments (poor housing 
conditions)
• Lack of critical infrastructure (water, sanitation, electricity, etc.)
• Poor environmental & resource management
• Increased environment & resource degradation & overconsumption (natural resource crises)
•Increased extreme weather events resulting in higher frequency & severity of hazards
•Human environmental damage: deforestation, pollution Oxygen capacity 
• Compromised systems of good governance & organisational systems
•Poor performance of lower-level government structures
• Insufficient dissemination of information from early warning systems or insufficient response to warning systems
• Limited burn facilities available in the country (specialised commodities needed, isolation units for burns that need high IPC standards that meet international regulations)
Non-health vulnerabilities: 
•Poor economic growth & debt crisis
•Unemployment and low-income levels
•Fragile local economies
•Lack of skills & resources
Governance_and_Resouces:
Governance:
• Existing governance structures and communication strategies are 
in place to activate resources needed e.g., through NDMC, 
NATJOINTS, IMC, DJOC, ProvJOC
• Contingency Plans, e.g., business continuity plans for fires
• Emergency SOPs
• Debriefing and lessons learnt is a weakness
• Triaging system supports the access to care at a faster rate
Resources:
• There are financial resources to respond to health emergencies –
when a disaster is declared, disaster relief funds are activated
•There are human resources present that can support the response 
to health emergencies 
• Resources are available to respond to heat waves, although they 
might not be immediately available, they can be activated e.g.,
through multisectoral collaborations or through the private sector 
(PPE, Transportation, ambulances, human resources, IT health 
infrastructure)
• There are early warning systems for fires through the weather 
service
Health_Sector_Capacity:
• There are sufficient health governance coping capacities at 
national, provincial and local levels
• Existing human resources and physical resources can be 
activated to respond as required (Rapid response teams, 
Emergency Medical Services capacity, Casualty capacity, Primary 
healthcare capacity, Mortuary capacities, Hospital capacity – ICU, 
paediatric wards, Forensic pathology services) 
• Partnerships with the private sector and with other sectors can be 
activated to increase capacity
Non_Health_Sector_Capcity:
• All government sectors come together to respond to a health 
emergency including water, agriculture, education, communication 
etc. There is thus capacity in the non-health sector
• Multi sectoral teams
Commuty_Capacity:
• Civil organisations, and religious organisations have capacity to 
support communities to health emergencies
• NPO and NGOs (e.g., gift of the givers) support 
• Presence and active engagement of NGOs e.g., churches, civil 
rights groups etc.

Health_consequences:
Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, and dizziness at the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within two days to one week after the onset of the illness. Severe symptoms may be developed in some cases.                                                                                                                                             Three forms of RVF exist:                                                                                                   
1. Ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye), which sometimes accompanies the mild symptoms described above. Lesions on the eyes may occur 1-3 weeks after the onset of initial symptoms with patients reporting blurred and decreased vision. For many patients, lesions disappear after 10-12 weeks; however, for those with lesions occurring in the macula, approximately 50% of patients will have permanent vision loss.
2. Encephalitis, or inflammation of the brain, can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures. This occurs in less than 1% of patients and presents 1-4 weeks after the first symptoms appear. Though death from this is rare, neurological deficits, sometimes severe, may persist.
3. Hemorrhagic fever, occurs in less than 1% of overall RVF patients, but fatality for those who do develop these symptoms, is around 50%. Symptoms of hemorrhaging may begin with jaundice and other signs of liver impairment, followed by vomiting blood, bloody stool, or bleeding from gums, skin, nose, and injection sites. These symptoms appear within 2-4 days and death usually occurs 3-6 days after.

Health_consequences:
(1) Early symptoms of a rabies infection can include a fever with pain and unusual or unexplained tingling, pricking or burning sensation (paraesthesia) at the wound site.
(2) Furious rabies causes signs of hyperactivity, excitable behaviour, hydrophobia (fear of water) and sometimes aerophobia (fear of drafts or of fresh air). Death occurs after a few days due to cardio-respiratory arrest. 
(3) Paralytic rabies runs a less dramatic and usually longer course than the furious form. Muscles gradually become paralysed, starting at the site of the bite or scratch. A coma slowly develops and eventually death occurs

•Institutional Vunerability-

Vulnerability_Details:
• From literature review and outbreak reports, the large proportion of Lassa fever cases are among people of low socio-economic status
• Low awareness of Lassa fever control and preventive measures in rural communities
• Poor housing especially with crevices and poor refuse disposal
• Poor environmental hygiene/ Poor sanitation
• Cultural practices (e.g food processing methods, burial)
• Rat hunting in rural communities
• Inadequate access to basic health facility
• Bush burning, deforestation
Governance_and_Resouces:
Governance
• Emergency preparednesss and response plan is available at the national level but unavailable at the sub-national
• Available coordination mechanism (PHEOCs)
• Lassa fever research group at the national level 
Health Sector Capacities

Resources
• Availability of resources for emergency preparedness and response but there is no dedicated budgetline
Health_Sector_Capacity:
• Strong indicator base surveillance at the national & subnational level but weak event base surveillance at the sub-national. Weak animal surveillance and no environmental surveillance system
• availability of 40 bedded hospitals for infectious disease at about 30 states at sub-national
•Availability of trained personnel but insufficient infectious disease expert
•Availability of incident action plans, guidelines at national and most of the states
Commuty_Capacity: • Existing risk communication platforms in few states

Geographical_Area: KCT ( toutes les 31 ZS sur 31)
Exposure: 4 500 000 personnes
Vulnerability_Details:
• Faible niveau de vaccination de la population (moins de 2%)
• Afflux important des personnes déplacées/refoulées par moment
• Fréquence des échanges socioéconomiques avec la ville de Kinshasa, épicentre de la pandemie
• Non observance des mesures barrières par l'ensemble de la population
• Fausses croyances notammment culturelles et religieuses
•  Faible capacité logistiqude pour le referencement des patients
• Absence effective de la CSU surtout pour la prise des patients avec co-morbidité
•Manque d'eau en permanence dans la communauté et auniveau des structures de prise en charge

Health_consequences:
Complications immédiates: morsures, picotement inhabituel ou inexpliqué, piquant ou sensation de brûlure (paráéestiose) et hémorragies  sur le site de la plaie, forte létalité (100% de 2012 à 2015, source Rapport SENES KCT 2020).
Complications secondaires: psychose généralisée, surinfections des plaies, complications neuropsychiatriques ((excitabilité, hyperactivité, hydrophobie (peur de l'eau) et parfois de l'aérophobie (peur des brouillons ou d'air frais), paralysies), arret cardio-respiratoire, coma.

Health_consequences:
(1) Sudden onset of fever, cough (usually dry), headache, muscle and joint pain, severe malaise (feeling unwell), sore throat and a runny nose.
(2) Severe illness or death occur especially in people at high risk, such as pregnant women, children under 59 months, and the elderly. 
(3) Health care workers are at high risk acquiring influenza virus infection due to increased exposure to the patients and risk further spread particularly to vulnerable individuals.
(4) Hospitalisation due to seasonal influenza leads to losses in working days due to sickness, reduction in quality of life due to secondary infections, increased school absenteeism and increased use of hospital resources
(5) Socio-economic losses
6

Health_consequences: Immediate: Morbidity, overload of facilities. Mortality
Geographical_Area: All districts
Vulnerability_Details:
Miss use of antibitiotics, Over the counter sales of antibiotics, poor quality drugs, over prescriptions of antibiotics both in Humans and Animals, use of antibiotics in animal feed as growth promoters,
Drug resistance index as per the MAAP survey75.1%, Increasing resistance rates OF 9 selected pathogen as per the WHO pathogen priority list is at 85% as per the GLASS reports from 2019-2022
Poor prescription habits and use as depicted in Point prevalence surveys GPPS 2022
Coping_capacity_details:
Governance:National Action Plan on AMR in place and in implementation phase
Multisectoral coordination system in place and function
Institutiona;lization of a governing system through the AMRCC
Resources:secured funding through donor, Fleming Fund,WHO, ESCA-HQ,CHAI,  and Malawi government has committed resources through a government main funding stream budget
Health Sector Capacity: 15 laboratories (3 animal Health, 12 Human Health) have the capacity to do AMR detection through AST testing, a data central warehouse has been established with IT infrastructure and workforce, Antimicrobial stewardship committees have been established and are active in all the 12 facilities.Point prevalence surveys on antimicrobial consumption and use are routinely collected to check prescription and uptake of antibiotics
community engagements: awareness and eductional programs are in progress, on going community activities are in progress on deliberative conversation in communities in blantyre, chikwawa and lilongwe, participation on world antibiotic awareness week is done yearly
Trained health workforce in AMR,AMS Through a program called qualifying workforce on antimicrobial resistance facilitated by ASLM and the fleming fund,An MSC-Antimicrobial stewardship is in operational at KUHES where the first graduates graduated in 2021.

Health_consequences: Immediate:Trauma, morbidity, mortality, psychological shock, skin burns, gastrointestinal syndrome, neurologic syndrome, Long Term: cancer, genetic defects, cardiovascular effects
Geographical_Area: Northern Malawi (Kayerekera uranium mine in Karonga), mining sites (coal and rare earth minerals) and major road construction sites across the country, Hospital with radiography facilities across the country, Mzimba, Blantyre
Exposure: 150000 Workers at the mine and surrounding areas including HCW at the cancer centre
Vulnerability_Details: Proximity to mine, proximity to rivers contaminated with uranium (radioactive particles), level awareness, absence of surveillance systems and management of radiology exposure treatment centres, capacity to detect
Coping_capacity_details: Availability of legal framework, coordination mechanism, ambulances, HES

Health_consequences: Immediate: Traumatic injuries, mortality, Long Term: chronic psychological disorder
Geographical_Area: Karonga, Mtandire, Mgona, Chisapo, Areas 22, 23, 47, 49, 18, Lilongwe, Chikwawa, Nsanje, Zomba-Lake Chirwa, Masasa- Mzuzu. Ndirande, Chirimba-Blantyre, Nkhotakota, Salima
Vulnerability_Details: Structures along river banks, structures in flood prone areas, structures in tremor prone areas
Coping_capacity_details: Availability of legal framework, coordination mechanism (DODMA), referral hospitals, ambulances, HES, monitoring system, relocation provision, public awareness, response capacity

Hazard: Transportation accidents (RTA, Boat or Ferry capsize, air crash, maritime)
Health_consequences: Immediate: Traumatic injuries, morbidity, psychosocial stress, mortality, increased ambulance call-outs and slower response times, over load of facilities and services, diversion of resources, Long Term: physical disability, chronic mental disorders
Geographical_Area: Chiweta-Rumphi, Chikangawa-Mzimba, Nkhamenya-Kasungu, Mponela-Dowa, Lilongwe-City and Nathenje, Dedza-Golomoti, Linthipe and Khwekhwelere, Ntcheu, Balaka-Phalura, Blantyre-Lirangwe, Chikwawa-Milare, Nkhatabay-Mpamba, Nkhotakota-Dwambazi and Mkaika, Salima-Chipoka, Mangochi-Chimwala and Mpale, and along M1 road (Lilongwe, Kasungu, Blantyre, Mzimba,
Vulnerability_Details: Settlements and markets in high risk areas, road user behaviour, conditions of roads and road worthness of vehicles, weather conditions, limited capacity in the Health sector (No trauma centres in district hospitals)

Health_consequences:
(1) Trauma-related injuries and deaths from building collapse or secondary effects like drowning from tsunamis or burns from fires
(2) Infrastructural failure, including damage to health facilities and transportation
(3) Disrupted health services 
(4) Health workers may not be able to reach health facilities and medical supplies may be lost
(5) Environmental contamination 
(6) Increased need for mental health and pyschosocial support
Geographical_Area: Karonga, Salima, Nsanje, Lilongwe, Nkhatabay, Nkhotakota, Mangochi
Vulnerability_Details: Physical-poor quality buildings, settlements, population growth and density. Economic- poverty, Environmental-stability of ecosystem, Social-weak survelance system,level of awareness on tremors
Coping_capacity_details: Governance-DoDMA with response structures. Capacity-guidelines for safer house construction, response plans & programs, safe & basic health services. Resources-NDAF

Health_consequences:
(1) Malnutrition (including micronutrient deficiency and iron-deficiency anaemia)
(2) Food and water insecurity
(3) Increased risk of infectious diseases outbreaks (cholera, diarrhoea and pneumonia) and death due to malnutrition, lack of WASH and displacement
(4) Decrease of Household buying power and potential disruption of health services
(5) Increased stress and mental health disorders
(6) Further risk to those impacted by lung diseases, asthma or chronic diseases (heart, respiratory)
(7) Migration of population, forced to leave local areas
Geographical_Area: Balaka, Neno,Salima, Mwanza, Blantyre, Nsanje, Chikwawa, Phalombe, Mangochi,  Zomba, Ntcheu, Mchinji, Kasungu, Mzimba, Thyolo and Karonga Affecting mainly the eldery and young children
Vulnerability_Details:
•Economic- poverty, Environment-vegetation, poor land management. Social-lack of knowledge, lack of early warning information

Health_consequences:
(1) Drowning (accounts for 75% of deaths in flood disasters)
(2) Deaths from physical trauma, heart attacks, electrocution, carbon monoxide poisoning or fire associated with flooding
(3) Water- and vector-borne diseases, such as cholera, typhoid or malaria
(4) Injuries, such as lacerations or punctures from evacuations and disaster cleanup 
chemical hazards
(5) Mental health effects associated with emergency situations
(6) Disrupted health systems, facilities and services, leaving communities without access to health care 
(7) Damaged basic infrastructure, such as food and water supplies, and safe shelter.
Geographical_Area: Nsanje, Chikwawa, Mulanje, Phalombe, Zomba, Karonga,Nkhatabay, Rumphi, Salima, Lilongwe, Dedza, Mangochi, Machinga, Nkhotakota, Blantyre, Balaka, Thyolo
Vulnerability_Details:
•Physical-poor quality buildings, settlements, population growth and density. Economic- poverty,farming sytems, financing opportunities Environmental-stability of ecosystem,vegetation, poor land management Social-weak survelance system,lack of knowledge,access to early warning information, Gender aspects(women, old,Lactating....), political will

Coping_capacity_details:
Governance
•DoDMA with response structures to mitigate impacts of floods
•Well trained personnel managing the governance structures for floods 
Health Sector Capacities
•Conducting outreach services for health care delivery (curative, preventive, promotive)
•Disease surveillance activities such as predicting disease outbreaks and how to mitigate these
Non-health Sector Capacities
•Seasonal weather forecasting by DCCMS
•surge and rescue operations by security organs
Community
•Constructtion of safenets/havens in communities
•redirecting the floods water to reach homes through construction of dikes
Resources
•humanitarian aid

Health_consequences: Avortements chez les animaux gestants et une forte mortalité chez les jeunes Immediates:Hémorragie ,déces, perturbation importante du systém de santé  Secondaires:Défaillance d'organe
Geographical_Area: Régionale, particulèrement les régions agropastorales ( les 2 hodh, Assaba , Gorgol, Guidimagha, Tagant ; Trarza, Brakna, HEC-HEG-ADRAR-TAGANT-GUIDI MAGHA)
Exposure: Eleveurs,  personnel des abattoirs, vétérinaires

Health_consequences: Asymptomatique chez les animaux, Cependant, chez l'homme on observe une fièvre brutale, faiblesse généralisée, une irritabilité, des céphalées, de vives douleurs dans les membres et la région lombaire,  conjonctives injectées, énanthème hémorragique du voile du palais,  et très souvent éruption constituée de fines pétéchies s’étendant du thorax et de l’abdomen à tout le reste du corps Conséquences immédiates: fièvre , douleurs aticulaires, musculaires, pertubation importante du système de santé Conséquences secondaires: syndrome hémorragique , défaillance d'organe, 30% de mortalité chez l'homme et fort potentiel d'infection nosocomiale
Geographical_Area: Régionale, particulèrement les régions agropastorales ( les 2 hodh, Assaba , Gorgol, Guidimagha, Tagant ; Trarza, Brakna)
Exposure: Eleveurs,  personnel des abattoirs, vétérinaires

Health_consequences:
Chez les oiseaux, il est observé une grave atteinte de l’état général, des signes respiratoires, digestifs et/ou nerveux diversement associés sur un seul ou plusieurs sujets 
 lésions de septicémie hémorragique. L’évolution vers la mort est rapide . Forme humaine : conséquences immédiates : fièvre, toux, myalgies , Coséquences secondaires : troubles respiratoires , insuffisance multiorgane et parfois décès
Geographical_Area: les régions limitrophes des parcs nationaux (Diawling et Arguin) et les autres zones humides (Tamourt Naaj, Mahmouda,  ,,,)
Exposure: Aviculteurs, vétérinaires, pêcheurs

Vulnerability_Details: Facteurs physiques: Les chasseurs, le personnel de santé, les régroupements socio-réligieux (funérailles, prières, mariages, baptêmes…), existence d'anciens malades d'Ebola           Facteurs socio-economiques: les personnes déplacées, la consommation et la manipulation des produits de chasse                                         Facteurs environnementaux:les conditions d'eau, hygiène et assainissement précaires,proximité avec des pays ayant eu des flambées épidémiques                                                        Facteurs du système de santé :accès limité (geographique, financier et barrières socio-culturelles) aux services de santé, faible ratio agent de santé par population (6 professionnels de santé/10 000 habitants), insuffisance de couverture maladie universelle

Health_consequences: Conséquences immédiates :  morbidité (déshydratation aigue sévère, choc hypovolemique,...) et mortalitée  (létalité à 40-50%) élevées, perturbations des services de santé (baisse de la demande et rupture de stock de médicaments et intrants), psychose (au sein de la population générale et du personnel de santé)                                                                                                                   Conséquences secondaires:  résurgence de certaines maladies (Rougeole, méningite..), complications des maladies chroniques (HTA, Diabète,VIH...)
Geographical_Area: Les régions (Kayes , Koulikoro,Ségou, Mopti,Tombouctou, Gao)
Exposure: Population totale des régions citées (15 355 742 habitants)
Vulnerability_Details: Facteurs physiques: le personnel de santé, les régroupements socio-réligieux (funérailles, prières, mariages, baptêmes…)                           Facteurs socio-economiques: conditions précaires des personnes déplacées                                                                  Facteurs environnementaux: les conditions d'eau, hygiène et assainissement précaires, l'insécurité alimentaire                                                                  Facteurs du système de santé: accès limité aux services de santé (geographique, financier et barrières socio-culturelles), faible ratio agent de santé par population (6 professionnels de santé/10 000 habitants), insuffisance de couverture maladie universelle
Governance_and_Resouces:
Gouvernance: Décret de nomination du coordinateur national des urgences sanitaires, Décret de désignation du point focal national RSI                                                 
Coordination: Désignation d'un point focal national RSI, DOUSP fonctionnel, DGSHP                                                        Plan de prévention et de riposte Choléra,  existence d'un comité technique de coordination
