Health_consequences: outbreak of waterborne diseases (e.g. diarrhoea, etc.)
Vulnerability_Details: Consumption of inadequate water, inadequate water supply, inadequate sanitation
Governance_and_Resouces: Lack of sufficient resources for the construction of adequate water supply systems

Health_consequences:
Traumatic injuries, psychological stress, mortality, increased ambulance calls and slower response times, overloading of hospitals and health services, public exposure to toxic substances, possible environmental pollution, diversion of resources, damage or loss of essential life support services: water, food, shelter, damage to infrastructure,
forced displacement of the population, security breaches and disruption of communication networks and
information flows.
Vulnerability_Details: The vulnerable population is located in risk zones where there are fault lines on the tectonic plate.
Governance_and_Resouces: The response capacity is low because we do not have trained personnel to respond to the event, we have not carried out simulation exercises, we have not identified safe places to shelter the populations.

Health_consequences: animal bites, deaths (drowning and dragging), water-borne diseases, food and vectors, forced population displacement, psychosocial stress, increased ambulance calls and slower response times, overloading of hospitals and health services, public exposure to toxic substances, possible pollution, diversion of resources, damage to infrastructure and essential life- support services: water, food, shelter, damage and loss of facilities, services, security breaches, disruption of communication networks and information flows and loss of medicines.
Vulnerability_Details: The vulnerable population lives in risk areas that are close to the Licungo, Zambezi, Pungue, Megaruma, Messalo, Monapo, Limpopo, Maputo and Pequenos Libombos rivers.
Governance_and_Resouces: The capacity is moderate because we have trained personnel, simulation exercises, pre-identified places for accommodation of the population, pre- positioning of goods and means for assistance in the first 72 hours, although there is a shortage of funds.

Health_consequences: Trauma, death and psychological stress, forced displacement and infrastructure destruction
Vulnerability_Details: Prospectors are vulnerable to this event because miners do not have the proper equipment and techniques to carry out the activity.
Governance_and_Resouces: The response capacity is low because we do not have trained staff.

Health_consequences:
animal bites, deaths (drowning, dragging and electrocution), water-borne diseases, electric shock, loss of medicine, forced displacement and destruction of social and economic
infrastructure
Vulnerability_Details:
The population is vulnerable because they live in areas at risk, live in precarious housing and have poor socio-economic
infrastructures.
Governance_and_Resouces: The capacity is moderate because we have trained personnel, simulation exercises, pre-identified places for accommodation of the population, pre- positioning of goods and means for assistance in the first 72 hours, although there is a shortage of funds.

Health_consequences: Malnutrition, health diseases (dehydration, heat cramps, heat stroke, diarrhoea, cholera and skin diseases), Morbidity (respiratory disease, diabetes mellitus, kidney disease, cardiovascular disease, stroke, mental health condition), hunger and food insecurity.
Vulnerability_Details: The population is vulnerable because they live in the risk zones called arid and semi-arid where there is low rainfall.
Governance_and_Resouces: The response capacity is low because the consequences of drought are not immediate and there is a delay in response.

Health_consequences:
traumatic injuries, carbon monoxide poisoning, psychosocial stress, death, damage to essential life support
infrastructure services: water, food, shelter, environmental
pollution, increased
ambulance calls and slower response times, overloading of hospitals and health services, diversion of resources and disruption of communication networks and
information flows.
Vulnerability_Details: Vulnerability is high because annually the country has suffered the event because of the hunting and clearing of cultivated areas.
Governance_and_Resouces: Response capacity is moderate.

Health_consequences: Health illnesses (dehydration, heat stroke and sunstroke), Morbidity (respiratory disease, hypertension, illnesses, diabetes mellitus, kidney disease, cardiovascular disease, stroke, mental health condition), forced population displacement, increased ambulance calls and slower response times, overburdened hospitals and health services, mortality and psychological stress.
Vulnerability_Details: Every year the country experiences heat waves due to climate change, where people live in these at-risk areas.
Governance_and_Resouces: The response capacity is low, we do not have trained personnel to respond to the event, there has not been a simulation exercise.

Health_consequences:
Injuries f rom slips and stumbles, cold illness (hypothermia and
f rostbite, immersion foot / trench foot), morbidity (cold, flu due to seasonal or pandemic flu, sore throat, norovirus, asthma, heart attacks), forced population displacement, increased ambulance calls and slower response times, overburdening of hospitals and health services and
mortality
Vulnerability_Details: Every year the country registers cold waves with temperatures below 10 degrees Celsius, mainly in June and July, where the populations are vulnerable.
Governance_and_Resouces: Response capacity is low. We have no trained personnel to respond to the event. There has not been a simulation exercise.

Health_consequences: Acute respiratory distress, neurological damage mortality, psychosocial effects, malnutrition; disruption of health services; multi organ failures
Vulnerability_Details: COVID-19 immunization coverage still low (health workers and only people with co-morbidities in Maseru are immunized) There are only 2 isolation facilities for Covid-19 in the country (Mafeteng and Berea)
Coping_capacity_details: National COVID-19 Secretariat and EOC are in place. COVID-19 regulations, frameworks and SOPs in place however, use of these documents should be strengthened. There is availability of human and financial resources, however these maybe insufficient should another wave come.

Health_consequences: Acute respiratory distress, morbidity and mortality
Vulnerability_Details: Population does not have immunity for the highly pathogenic influenza virus,   There is no vaccine,
Coping_capacity_details: Preparedness and Response plan in place, HPI is among the priority disease for surveillance (IDSR), healthcare workers have been trained, however, there are no resources earmarked for influenza outbreak response

Health_consequences: Morbidity and mortality, malnutrition, blindness, severe skin rashes, mental disability, paralysis, overload of facilities and services
Vulnerability_Details: 64% coverage of second dose of measles vaccine due to population hesitancy.
Coping_capacity_details: Disease Control program in existence, Immunization is routinely conducted, EPI operational plans are incorporated into the national health sector plan   Well trained staff to conduct supplementary immunization activities (SIA). Adequate cold chain management. District Rapid Response teams in place.

Health_consequences: Diarrhoea, vomiting, morbidity and mortality, psychological shock, overload of facilities and services, stomach cramps, high fever
Vulnerability_Details: High number of unvaccinated stray dogs, high incidence of dog bites (20% of the dogs tested after a dog bites reported were positive for rabies). In accessibility of anti-rabies vaccine (in hospitals only not health centres)
Coping_capacity_details: Rabies surveillance is a part of priority disease of IDSR. Anti-rabies vaccines for humans are available, however, there are insufficient suppliers.  There is collaboration between the human and animal health sectors.

Health_consequences: Dog bites (Trauma), overload of facilities and services, mortality, Morbidity as encephalitis,
Vulnerability_Details: Socio-cultural practice (A dead cow should be eaten and not buried).              Low vaccination coverage among animals
Coping_capacity_details: Existence of surveillance system for anthrax with good testing capacity.  There is collaboration between human and animal sectors on anthrax.  There is adequate capacity to manage cutaneous lesions.

Health_consequences: Morbidity and mortality, respiratory effects, neurological effects, cutaneous lesions.
Vulnerability_Details: High HIV prevalence (25%) predisposes these population to opportunistic infections and therefore erratic use of antimicrobial medicines.  - Uncontrolled and irrational use antimicrobials medicines - No surveillance system for antimicrobial medicines consumption and antimicrobial resistance. Low risk communication and education among the public and health professionals. There is no financial support earmarked for AMR. Inadequate research on AMR.
Coping_capacity_details: Draft National Action    Plan in place, however activities not incorporated into the national health sector operational plan. Governance and coordination structure for AMR in place.

Health_consequences: Severe Systemic infections such as Heart infection, bones infection, lung infection, costly treatment for infections, strain of healthcare resources, longer hospital stay in severe cases.
Vulnerability_Details: Landlocked by RSA which has a high load of international travellers.  International travel.  The population does not have immunity.  High number of migrant workers. Absence of event based /communit- based surveillance
Coping_capacity_details: Ebola surveillance incorporated into IDSR guidelines. Available trained human resources, simulation exercise is done

Health_consequences: Morbidly and mortality, multi-organ failure, psychological effects, overload of health services
Vulnerability_Details: Poor sanitation and hygiene     Inaccessibility of health facilities
Coping_capacity_details: Typhoid fever surveillance is part of the priority diseases of IDSR. Existence and operational WASH   program in the districts

Health_consequences: Diarrhoea, vomiting, morbidity and mortality, psychological shock, overload of facilities and services, stomach cramps,
Vulnerability_Details: Reliance of importation of food stuff from RSA
Coping_capacity_details: There is capacity for food inspection at both PoE and inland supported by public health legislation. However, there is limited testing capacity. The country is on the process of developing new food safety policy

Health_consequences: Morbidity and mortality, severe dehydration, anemia
Vulnerability_Details: Poor sanitation and hygiene     Inaccessibility of health facilities
Coping_capacity_details: Existence of surveillance system for shigellosis with good testing capacity.  Existence and operational WASH   program in the districts

Health_consequences: Asphyxiation, Fire burns, physical injuries, morbidities due to inhalation of the gas, death, post traumatic stress (PTS),  structural damages and pollution (air, soil and water)
Vulnerability_Details: No buffer zones between communities and gas depots, lack of coordination mechanisms, presence of vulnerable groups in depot vicinity(elderly, ill, children, health coverage is high, unavailability of various first responders such as:-  trained community responders - inefficient ambulance services  - low capacity of emergency rooms for mass causality care  - inefficient fire and rescue services,   - Lack of emergency routes
Coping_capacity_details: Physical access to health services, Emergency Services available (but inadequate ambulances sub-standard, shortage of human resources), Medical insurance service providers available but the majority of communities are not health-insured.  Sensitization done but not routinely thus communities not well informed of the dangers, Legal framework available (e.g. Environment Act) but not well adhered to.

Hazard: Transportation accidents (RTA, Boat or Ferry capsize, air crash, maritime)
Health_consequences: Injuries (soft tissues, fractures, head injuries, burns) disabilities, death, post-traumatic stress, stress on health facilities, loss of livelihoods, structural damages (road furniture, building and vehicles)
Vulnerability_Details: Unavailability of various first responders such as:-    trained community responders    - inefficient ambulance services  - low capacity of emergency rooms for mass causality care,  - inefficient fire and rescue services,   - lack of coordinated RTA awareness  campaigns,  - lack of coordination with relevant sectors in response to RTAs, - Lack of emergency routes
Coping_capacity_details: Emergency Medical Services are established (but have low capacity human, equipment), Health sector strategic and operational plans available (but do not include RTAs,) Laws available to impose fines on offenders (but penalties are lenient.) Blood transfusion services are available though blood supply in minimal.

Health_consequences: Injuries, disabilities, death, post-traumatic stress, stress on health facilities, Loss of livelihood
Vulnerability_Details: Non-compliance to building standards and codes (e.g. electrical safety, illegal connections, bad safety practices (overloading electrical sockets), vandalism etc.), Building without building permits, Inadequate knowledge among communities on fire safety,
Coping_capacity_details: Health sector plans do not address fire safety, Emergency Medical Services are established (but have low capacity human, equipment) Training and Capacity building on fire safety are being conducted but they are not widespread enough due to shortage of resources (human, material). The Fire Brigade Department is established to responds to fires but it is not fully adequate because of shortages of Resources (staff and equipment) Structural fires insurance covers are offered by a wide range of companies; however not many buildings are covered yet.

Health_consequences: Mortality due to drowning, physical injuries, Disruption of health services (destruction of health facilities), Waterborne and Water-washed diseases (disruption of water supply), Malnutrition (long term effect), Water pollution, (chemicals), disruption of health services due power outage
Vulnerability_Details:
Areas at risk are dominated by rural communities with low access to health services and availability of vulnerable group (children and the elderly), Dam failure emergencies not part of health sector strategic and operational plans, unavailability of various first responders such as:
•trained community responders
•inefficient ambulance services
•low capacity of emergency rooms for mass causality care 
•inefficient rescue services
•lack of continued awareness campaigns
•EPR plans not tested
Coping_capacity_details: Environmental Management Plans and EPR plans and Early warning systems available but not simulated, Downstream communities have been sensitized on evacuation protocols during emergencies

Health_consequences: Drowning, Inaccessibility to health services, Erosion, Increase burden on health services, waterborne outbreaks, Psychological stress, food insecurity
Vulnerability_Details: Geography location (people living in sloppy terrain and riverbanks), access to health facility (destruction of road and bridges and poor roads, distance travelled), sanitation (unsafe drinking water)
Coping_capacity_details: Legal frameworks (Disaster Management Act 1997, National Multi-hazard Contingency plan 2020-2023 etc.), structures (Disaster management structures, health facilities and workers etc.) Disaster Management Fund. But functionality and sustainability of response mechanisms is limited due to inadequate financial resources. Lack of Political will and commitment. Working in silos.

Health_consequences: Inaccessibility to health services, Increase burden on health services, frost bite lead to disability, Mortality, Defaulting, Psychological stress, food insecurity,
Vulnerability_Details: Geographic location (people living highlands areas), Inaccessibility to communication facilities (e,g. phones, radios), socio economic status (low purchasing power, herd boys etc.).  Inaccessibility to health care services. Social behaviour (Ignorance to early warning information).
Coping_capacity_details: Legal frameworks (Disaster Management Act 1997, National Multi-hazard Contingency plan 2020-2023 etc.), structures (Disaster management structures, health facilities and workers etc.) Disaster Management Fund, Rescue teams/air rescue (helicopters) available. But functionality and sustainability of response mechanisms is limited due to inadequate financial resources. Lack of Political will and commitment. Working in silos.

Health_consequences: Food insecurity, malnutrition, psychological stress, negative coping mechanisms (teenage pregnancy, prostitution, GBV, etc.), Hygiene practices are compromised, waterborne outbreaks, other foodborne disease outbreaks,
Vulnerability_Details: Socio-economic factors (Whole population, low purchasing power to prepare for the event, soaring prices). Water and Sanitation (shortage of water compromised WASH practices) Depletion of water sources, Food Security (shortage of food and high food price), Forced traveling distance and time spend to fetching water, limited health services (e.g.  delivery services compromised),
Coping_capacity_details: Legal frameworks (Disaster Management Act 1997, National Multi-hazard Contingency plan 2020-2023 etc.), structures (Disaster management structures, health facilities and workers etc.) Disaster Management Fund, vulnerability assessment. But functionality and sustainability of response mechanisms is limited due to inadequate financial resources. Lack of Political will and commitment. Working in silos. .

La mort de diverses espèces animales vivant dans les forêts, La brûlure du sol le rendant stérile après quelques années, Les érosions par manque d'arbre pour protéger le sol et éviter ces érosions, Les éboulements provoquant l'ensablement des rizières, Le tarissement des sources d'eau, Les bouleversements dans le changement climatique, La pollution de l'air, destruction de la flore et la faune, mais aussi des cultures, la secheseresse, la famine, la malnutrition, le tarissement des cours d'eau.
danger environnementaux, brulure physique, Famine

La santé des enfants et des personnes âgées  devient très fragile, denrées alimentaires rares et chères, ressources en eau peu abondantes, sols érodés et bétail affaibli, conflits juridiques et sociaux , Dimunition des poissons vivant dans l'eau et animaux qui s'abreuvent aux points d'eau, arbres plus secs et déshydratés ce qui peut causer leur mort, l'alimentation et l'évacuation des eaux ménagères ne se font pas correctement, Diminution du niveau des rivières, des fleuves et des nappes d'eau, incendies  souvent nombreux.

Perte de la biodiversité  (animaux et vegetaux) L'agravation des maladies, l'agravation  des catastrophes naturelles, la dimunition de la ressource en eau, le changement  climatique, destruction de la flore et la faune, mais aussi des cultures. Conséquences tardives: la secheseresse, la famine, la malnutrition, le tarissement des cours d'eau.

Health_consequences:
Immediate: upper respiratory tract infections, severe acute respiratory
syndrome, hospital surge.
Secondary: trigger multiple organ failure, worsening underlying health
conditions, disruption of routine health services & death
Geographical_Area:
Four waves since March 2020, with 157,376 cases and 1,408 (CFR 0.89%)
deaths and Positivity rate of 7.0% as at end Jan 2022. Geographically all 16
regions, but most affected GAR & AR. The areas most affected are densely
populated cities with high socio-economic activities
Exposure: The whole population is at risk
Vulnerability_Details:
Access to Health services: postponement of surgeries, disruption of
routine services like CWC, ANC, etc. Health Status: 4.7M fully vaccinated.
64% don't have access to safe water and 82% no access to basic sanitation, HPT
- 27% (Bosu & Bosu, 2021)
Governance_and_Resouces: Political commitment
Health_Sector_Capacity:
Access to Health services: 63 testing capacity
and all regions, 24 treatment/case management centres in all regions, triaging at
HFs, screening at KIA, vaccines available,
Commuty_Capacity:
High knowledge among community
members on control and prevention measures, infodemic management

Health_consequences:
Immediate: rising morbidity and death rate average of 50% for EVD.
Secondary: disruption of routine health services
Geographical_Area:
No case of EVD detected in Ghana, although Lassa (2015) and Dengue fevers
(2017). Major EVD outbreak occurred 2014-16 in West Africa total of 28,616
cases and 11,310 deaths (CFR 39.5%)
Exposure: The whole population is at risk
Vulnerability_Details:
High - Access to Health services: disruption provision of routine health services
e.g. CWC, ANC, etc. Health Status: Not vaccinated, proximity to primary host,
hunting activities, appetite for bush meat
Governance_and_Resouces:
National preparedness and response plan, Availability of functional
testing sites - NMIMR & KCCR, , Case holding rooms at POEs, HWs trained,
increased community awareness of EVD & other VHFs but no dedicated
funding

Health_consequences:
Immediate: diarrhoea and dehydration and death when not managed timely.
Secondary: put pressure on existing capacities of HF
Geographical_Area:
Cholera is becoming endemic in Ghana with cyclical epidemics every 4 to 6
years. Most recent outbreaks were 2012 and 2014-15. In 2021, 2 cases
confirmed in ER. Geographically, it is wide spread, with the 2014-15 outbreaks
affecting all then 10 regions and 60% of districts of the country. Areas mostly
affected are slums
Exposure: The whole population is at risk
Vulnerability_Details:
Access to health services: put pressure on existing capacities of HFs
Health Status: 64% don't have access to safe water and 82% no access to basic
sanitation, low access to improved toilet facility
Governance_and_Resouces:
National preparedness and response plan, Availability of functional
testing sites at districts and region, effective case management protocol, HWs
trained,
Commuty_Capacity: Increased community awareness on cholera but no dedicated funding

Health_consequences:
Immediate: high levels of morbidity and mortality. Secondary: hearing loss,
seizures, limb weakness, difficulties with vision, speech, language, memory,
and communication
Geographical_Area:
Occurs each year during the dry season (Oct-Apr). Major outbreaks happened in
1984/85 and 1996/97. Geographically, Northern parts, but has become
widespread with most recent major outbreak in 2015/16 which affected 7 of the
then 10 regions with 20% CFR. Areas mostly affected are rural-urban
communities
Exposure: Districts in the meningitis belt, regular travellers e.g. Nomadics, traders, etc.
Vulnerability_Details:
Access to Health services: put pressure on existing capacities of HFs
Health Status: vaccination status, 5 regions vulnerable fall in the meningitis belt,
but wide geographical spread in recent times, in particular the 2015 -2016
outbreaks affecting 7/10 regions in the country housing occupancy &
ventilation
Governance_and_Resouces:
National preparedness and response plan, Availability of functional
testing sites at districts and region, effective case management protocol, HWs
trained
Commuty_Capacity:
Low community awareness in non-endemic regions with no dedicated
funding

Health_consequences:
Immediate: High morbidity and mortality. Secondary: severe abdominal pain,
jaundice and liver failure, renal insufficiency, and haemorrhagic signs such as
bleeding from the mouth, nose, eyes, or stomach.
Geographical_Area:
Ghana is endemic, with outbreaks in Recent severe recent outbreaks in 1993/94,
1996/97. For 2021, 9/16 regions reported 202 suspected, 70 confirmed cases
and 35 deaths.
Areas mostly affected are high mosquito density and where most people have
little or no immunity due to lack of vaccination.
Exposure: The whole population is at risk
Vulnerability_Details:
Access to Health services: put pressure on existing capacities of HFs
Health Status: more than 5.3M vaccinated in 2020 (10-60yrs), All regions
vulnerable fall in the YF belt, availability of Nomadic populations
Governance_and_Resouces:
National preparedness and response plan, Availability of functional
testing sites at national level, effective vaccine available, inspection of vaccine
cards for travellers
Commuty_Capacity: low community awareness with no dedicated funding

Health_consequences:
Immediate: high mortality rate characterized by lower respiratory tract diseases.
Secondary: pneumonia, bronchitis, and kidney failure
Geographical_Area:
No human case recorded in all outbreaks in Ghana. Since 2007, 703,966 bird
mortality has been recorded in Ghana, out of which, 555,227 were culled as
containment measures in 159 farms. Geographically, 10/16 regions affected.
Exposure: The whole population is at risk
Vulnerability_Details:
General population and military living in close quarters such as
barracks are in close proximity to poultry and wet-bird markets. 4 strains
circulating in Ghana. Evidence of human infection in Egypt with R0= 0.23.
Frequent outbreaks among birds.
Governance_and_Resouces:
Government has finalized the Animal Health bill for the consideration of
Parliament to apply sanctions against recalcitrant farmers. Budgeted 44M for
compensation, functional NTCC, functional NIC, ongoing influenza sentinel
surveillance in 29 sites.
Commuty_Capacity:
Among farmers, increased in education and awareness
creation by the media on HPAI detection, prevention and control

Health_consequences:
Immediate: lower respiratory tract disease
Secondary: Respiratory failure, put pressure on limited ventilators at hospitals.
Geographical_Area:
Latest pandemic 2009 - H1N1 (Over 18,000.deaths). In Ghana, 141 suspected
cases and 40 contacts with 14 deaths. Geographically, all regions have reported
cases of H1N1 since 2009
Exposure: The whole population is at risk
Vulnerability_Details:
General population and military and student in boarding schools in
close proximity to pigs and wet-pig markets
Governance_and_Resouces:
High - Functional NTCC, functional NIC, ongoing influenza sentinel
surveillance in 29 sites.
Commuty_Capacity:
Increased in education and awareness among military
and student population

Health_consequences: Secondary: Disability, Post-Traumatic Stress Syndrome
Geographical_Area:
A total of 1,115 casualties were recorded in 2020. (MTTD). Geographically, the
whole country, mainly Greater Accra, Ashanti, Central, Bono regions
It occurs in both urban and rural areas.
Exposure:
Population at risk are commuters, communities living along the highways and
pedestrians especially school children
Vulnerability_Details:
Human error in driving, bad road structure, Bad pedestrian behaviour. Some vehicles are in poor condition, weak enforcement of road
regulations, Environmental factors e.g. poor visibility
Governance_and_Resouces:
Availability and functioning of government institutions NRSC,
MTTD, DVLA, Ministry of Roads and Highways
Available and functional emergency response agencies, NAS, GNFS, ERs,
NADMO, MTTD,
Commuty_Capacity: community response teams

Health_consequences:
Primary: Severe trauma, Mortality, Disability, Post-Traumatic Stress
Syndrome(Immediate)
Secondary: Post-Traumatic Stress Syndrome(Delayed), Disability
Geographical_Area:
In recent times, in January 2015, Ethiopian Airline skidded off the runway and
in October 2015, Starbow airline reported a crash. No fatalities recorded for
both accidents. Previously, in June 2012, Allied Air Boeing 727 accident killed
10 people in Accra. Then in June 2000, Airlink Fokker F-27 from Tamale to
Accra 7 were killed. (Bureau of Aircraft accidents and archives).
Geographically, airports in Accra, Kumasi, Tamale, Wa, Ho and Takoradi.
For, population setting, may occur anywhere but most likely to occur in urban
areas where airports are located
Exposure:
Population at risk are people living and working within and around airport and
passengers
Vulnerability_Details:
Inadequate airport infrastructure in some regions e.g. state of the runway,
communication gadgets etc. Encroachment of airport lands
Environmental conditions e.g. inclement weather, lightning strikes
Pilot error, air traffic controller errors Mechanical errors; flaws inherent in the
aircraft design, maintenance errors
Governance_and_Resouces:
Good airport safety standards e.g. Improvement in traffic control
and landing aids Aircraft accident and incident investigation and prevention
bureau ACT 2022, ACT 1028 Proper pilot training Good airline safety and
maintenance standards

Health_consequences:
Primary: Severe trauma, Mortality, Drowning, Post-Traumatic Stress
Syndrome(Immediate)
Secondary: Post-Traumatic Stress Syndrome(Delayed),
Geographical_Area:
In November 2021, 7 Students drowned in Saboba district. Death in Ghana due
to drowning reached 1,206 or 0.6% of total deaths (WHO, 2018).
Geographically, mainly areas along the Volta river and other coastal areas as
well as flood-prone areas Population setting, mostly rural areas but occasionally
occurs in urban areas as well
Exposure:
Population at risk are people living along water bodies who depend on water
transportation or fishing as livelihood
Vulnerability_Details:
Poor water transport vessels, Mechanical errors; breakdown of outboard
motors, Poor or non-existing safety gadgets ,
Environmental factors including bad weather, tree stumps
Inadequate regulatory regime for water transport
Human errors such as overloading
Governance_and_Resouces:
Good marine regulatory infrastructure Maintenance of marine transport
vessels Availability of marine safety equipment such as live jackets, etc.
Removal of tree stumps, weeds on water ways
Safety education and awareness to marine industry operators on issues such as
overloading, etc.

Health_consequences:
Primary: Severe trauma, Mortality, Post-Traumatic Stress
Syndrome(Immediate)
Secondary: Disability, Post-Traumatic Stress Syndrome(Delayed)
Geographical_Area:
In October 2020, 22 persons died in a building collapse in Akyem Batabi (GBC
news). During the period from 2000 - 2016, Ghana recorded 123 injuries and 23
deaths out of 15 reported structural collapse most notably the Melcom disaster
at Achimota (Researchgate.net). Geographically, country wide, experienced
mainly in urban areas as well as poorly structured buildings (mud houses) in the
rural areas Population setting is mostly urban and some isolated cases in rural
areas
Exposure: Population at risk are construction workers and occupants in the building
Vulnerability_Details:
Weak enforcement of building regulations, Use of sub-standard
building material, Enforcement of safety regulations. Improper maintenance of
building (i.e. poor maintenance culture).
Governance_and_Resouces:
Existence of emergency response agencies (i.e. NAS, GNFS, GAF,
GHS, NADMO, Police, etc.) Existence of State Institutions (i.e. Min. of Local
Govt., Min. of Works & Housing) for policy & response.
Commuty_Capacity:
Existence of Social support structures (i.e. extended family systems, Religious
bodies, etc.)

Health_consequences:
Primary: Gas and fume inhalation resulting in asphyxiation and acute
respiratory distress, injuries (i.e. burns), fatalities from gas explosion/fire
Secondary: Post-Traumatic Stress Syndrome(Delayed)
Geographical_Area:
In October 2017, a large explosion occurred at a liquefied natural gas station
located around Atomic Junction in Madina, Accra -. 7 deaths and 132 people
were injured. Geographically, oil refineries in Western, Greater Accra, Ashanti
regions. Gas leakages and spillage from transportation of fuel tankers may
happen nationwide. Population setting is more likely to occur in the urban areas
Exposure:
Population at risk are workers in the refineries, people living around refineries,
along highways, around fuel stations and drivers of haulage trucks and other
road users, also domestic users
Vulnerability_Details:
Weak enforcement of regulations. Enforcement of safety regulations.
Poor siting of fuel/gas stations. Improper maintenance culture. Low safety
awareness among populace. Improper storage/handing of combustible
goods/substanc.
Governance_and_Resouces:
Existence of Government Institutions for policy & enforcement (i.e.
Min. of Loc. Govt. GNFS, etc.) Installation of fire protective/alarm devices
equipment (i.e. fire extinguisher, smoke detectors, alarm, sprinkler, etc.).
Existence of Capacity for management of health consequences. Periodic
Educational Programmes/Sensitization.

Health_consequences:
Primary: Burns and wounds, acute respiratory distress, Mortality
Secondary: Chronic diseases
Geographical_Area:
Small-scale and illegal artisanal mining (Galamsey) have polluted several
communities’ water sources with arsenic and mercury. Significant cyanide spills
occurred in 2001-2003 in the Tarawa mining areas resulted in high pollution of
rivers and wetlands. E-waste. Geographically, the whole country. Population
setting are the urban and rural areas
Exposure:
Population at risk are workers and people living in the industrial areas, farmers
and users of chemicals
Vulnerability_Details:
Enforcement of safety regulations. Improper maintenance culture. Low safety awareness among populace. Improper
storage/handling of chemicals/substances.
Governance_and_Resouces:
Existence of Government Institutions for policy & enforcement (i.e.
Min. of Energy, Min. of Loc. Govt., EPA, NRSC. GNFS, Min. of Transport,
etc.) Existence of Capacity for management of health consequences.
Periodic Educational Programmes/Sensitization

Health_consequences:
Immediate/: Deterministic Effects i.e. Acute radiation syndrome
(ARS), skin burns, sterility, Skin Burns, Hypothyroidism, Mortality, Erythema,
Teratogenesis
Secondary: Stochastic or Hereditary effect [i.e. cancer and hereditary effects
(i.e. Mutation such as Chromosome aberrations, Gene mutations) , Cataract
Geographical_Area:
No major nuclear or radiological incident/accident reported in Ghana.
Operational incidents reported and loss of radioactive sources. Geographically,
the whole country (i.e. people and environment). Population setting:
Settlements near nuclear installations. During transport of radioactive material.
Exposure:
Population at risk are workers and people living near nuclear installations and
the environment
Vulnerability_Details:
Lack of or inadequate safety culture (i.e. management, quality control,
training and qualifications of workers) Inadequate training, Failure to use survey
meter; Equipment Failure; Safety procedures not followed; Lack of safety
programs), Inadequate capacity of emergency response team
Lack of specialized health care for radiation injuries
Governance_and_Resouces:
Existence of Regulatory Body (Nuclear Regulatory Authority), Other
Agencies such as Ghana Atomic Energy Commission, NADMO, etc.
NADMO sub-committee on Nuclear/Radiological emergency National
Emergency Response Plan [i.e. National Nuclear and Radiological Emergency
Response Plan (NNRERP)]. Capacity of emergency response team
Availability of Human Resource Inventory of Radiation sources Access to
specialized health care for radiation injuries & laboratory testing capacity for
monitoring, identification and assessment of radiation exposure

Health_consequences:
Primary: Burns (skin and lungs), Gas and fume inhalation resulting in
asphyxiation and acute respiratory distress
Minor trauma and crush injuries due to explosions, Morbidity, Mortality
Secondary: Post-traumatic stress syndrome
Geographical_Area:
There has been an increase in fire outbreaks from January - October 2019, from
4623 - 5355 for the same period in 2020. In 2020, 222 lives were lost and about
1125 injuries were reported as well. (Graphic online). Mainly Domestic,
industrial, vehicular, institutional, electrical installations, commercial, bush
fires, refuse. Geographically, the whole country, mainly Ashanti, Greater Accra,
North East Population setting: Both Urban and Rural areas
Exposure:
Entire population is at risk, especially farmers, hunters, industrial/factory
workers, drivers
Vulnerability_Details:
Enforcement of safety regulations. Poor siting of fuel/gas stations. Improper
maintenance culture. Low safety awareness among populace.
Improper storage/handling of combustible
Lack of fire hydrants & inadequate water in the hydrants. Suspected arsonist
activities. Poor electrical wiring systems/sub-standard electrical cables.
Threat of desertification/bad farming practices.
Governance_and_Resouces:
Partial - Existence of Government Institutions for policy & enforcement (i.e.
Min. of Local Govt. GNFS, etc.),
Non_Health_Sector_Capcity:
Installation of fire protective/alarm devices
equipment (i.e. fire extinguisher, smoke detectors, alarm, sprinkler, etc.).

Health_consequences:
Immediate: Short-term exposure to respirable dust can cause irritation of the
upper respiratory tract and the skin.
Severe trauma, death, Barotrauma to the ear, Reaction from drinking polluted
water from exposed chemicals
Secondary: Long-term cumulative exposure respirable dust in workers is likely
to develop into silicosis, silico-tuberculosis, pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB),
obstructive airways disease and occupational asthma, Heavy metal poisoning
e.g. affects kidney, brain and bones
Geographical_Area:
A total of 202 fatal and non-fatal injuries over a ten year period; 2008 - 2017,
Eric Stemn, 2019, (tip of the iceberg). Geographically, Western, Eastern,
Northern, Upper East, Upper West, Ashanti regions. Population setting: More in
the rural areas and some urban areas as well
Exposure: Population at risk are Mine Workers and Community around the mining areas
Vulnerability_Details:
Weak enforcement of regulations (i.e. safety, siting, etc.). Improper
maintenance culture. Low safety awareness among populace.
Improper storage/handling of combustible. Illegal mining activities.
Indiscriminate sale of lands
Governance_and_Resouces:
Existence of Government Institutions for policy & enforcement (i.e. Min.
of Lands &Nat. Res, EPA, MC, GAEC, MoH, etc.)
Installation of fire protective/warning systems Existence of Capacity for
management of health consequences. Periodic Educational
Programmes/Sensitization. Role of Traditional Authorities.

Health_consequences:
Primary: injury, death, loss of biodiversity, Dust inhalation, asphyxiation respiratory distress
Secondary: mental and psychosocial problems, physical disability, water-diseases, destruction of Health facilities
Geographical_Area:
2 major earthquakes, 18 Dec 1636 - Accra
24 Jun 1939 – Accra - 6.5 Richter scale magnitude (MR) – (killed 17 injured 1350). Geographically, epicentres in coastal boundary and Akuapem
fault zones.
Densely populated urban areas mostly.
Exposure: Population at risk estimated at 2 million
Vulnerability_Details:
The earthquake prone areas in Ghana tend to be urban and populated.
This makes the population susceptible to damaging effect of the hazards.
Governance_and_Resouces:
The national earthquake preparedness and response framework has been
developed. The framework is yet to be implemented and funding yet to secured.

Health_consequences:
Immediate: Drowning, injury, electrical shock (in urban areas), snake bite (in
rural areas), death. 
Secondary: mental and psychosocial problems, physical disability, disruption of
health facilities. Loss of drinking water, severe water contamination and loss of
sewage disposal facilities leading to risk of water borne diseases such as cholera
and typhoid fever.
Geographical_Area:
Flooding is usually an annual occurrence. Most devastating one occurred on 3rd
June 2015, in Accra - 212.8 mm of rainfall was recorded which claimed over
150 lives as a result of an explosion of a fuel filling station at Kwame Nkrumah
Circle.
2017 - 20 coastal floods were recorded. Affected 27 coastal communities.
Exposure:
Almost all regions have experienced flooding in the past especially Greater
Accra
Vulnerability_Details:
Every year the country experience flooding in the urban areas during the
rainy seasons. Construction of buildings on water ways
Governance_and_Resouces:
Some governmental structures such as NADMO, 48 Regiment of GAF,
Police, Fire Service, NAS, etc. in place for rescue operations but no dedicated
and sustainable sources of funding. However limited skill sets and well
equipped facilities for management of victims within the health sector is lacking

Health_consequences:
Immediate: Skins cracks and infections ,dehydration, heat strokes
Secondary: Malnutrition; micronutrient deficiencies
Disease outbreaks (water-borne diseases), decline in water availability and
quality
Geographical_Area:
Severe droughts in 1968-1973, 1982-1984, 1990-1992 with the drought of
1983/1984 being the most significant that led to extensive national food
insecurity (Ofori-Sarpong 1986)
Nationwide but mainly in the Northern Savannah zone of the country.
Exposure:
Mostly rural and peri-urban in Northern ecological zone
Estimated Population of about
Vulnerability_Details:
Historical events and evidence point to the fact that droughts are rare.
However, areas where these events happen are likely to be agrarian. Drought
lead to famine, malnutrition, waterborne diseases, and death, and severely
affects vulnerable groups like women, children and the elderly.
Governance_and_Resouces:
There is a general lack of structures for food security and water
conservation in the event of drought. Provision of silos for storing grains,
dugout wells and boreholes, irrigation systems etc. is lacking.
Non_Health_Sector_Capcity:
There aren't
adequate health facilities and logistics for the management of affected victims.

Health_consequences:
Primary: Drowning, destruction of Health facilities, Death, injury
Secondary: Water-borne Disease, Malnutrition; micronutrient deficiencies,
mental and psychosocial problems, physical disability.
Geographical_Area:
Recent tidal wave and coastal flooding in Keta, Ketu South and Anloga districts
Geographical: Mostly coastal regions.
Exposure: Worst case scenario in Keta is 10,000 people displaced in 2017.
Vulnerability_Details:
There are settlements very close to the coast. Illegal activities such as sand
winning on the beaches makes them more susceptible to extreme events. It
causes displacement, disruption to essential services and vulnerable groups such
as the elderly, women, children and people with co-morbidities.
Governance_and_Resouces:
There is some health management capacity to manage the health effects
of sea level rise. However beyond a certain threshold, capacities may be
overwhelmed.
Non_Health_Sector_Capcity: Sea defence walls are being constructed in some instances.

Health_consequences:
Primary: Physical and emotional trauma. Destruction of Health facilities, Death.
Secondary: Psychological trauma, Loss of essential services (health), Disability,
Diseases (respiratory, water-borne)
Geographical_Area:
Isolated incidents. Political flash points, ethnic flashpoints, Chieftaincy
disputes, land disputes (land guards)
Sporadic incidents in rural and urban areas. Ejura incident 2 lives claimed and 3
injured
Exposure: The whole population
Vulnerability_Details:
We have flash points (political, ethnic, religious, chieftaincy disputes
etc.) in some communities. Areas which are deprived with low standard of
living tend to be prone to civil unrest.
Governance_and_Resouces:
Law enforcement (police and other security and intelligence gathering
agencies are in place). Health emergency response services like the NAS,
Zipline and the national blood services exist. Emergency department of the
various health institutions also support.

Health_consequences:
Primary: Severe trauma, death, injury, Fear and panic
Secondary:
Disability, Post-Traumatic Stress Syndrome, Chronic illness.
Geographical_Area:
The country has not recorded any terrorist attack, however there is availability
of the threat
Exposure: Whole population is at risk
Vulnerability_Details:
Terrorism tends to be rare in occurrence but has very severe
consequences especially to women, children, elderly, etc.
Governance_and_Resouces:
Preventive mechanisms (police and other security and intelligence
gathering agencies are in place). Health emergency response services like the
NAS, Zipline and the national blood services exist. Emergency department of
the various health institutions also support. However there is a lack of
awareness in the general populace regarding what to do in the event of a
terrorist attack.

Response capability of most mines is  fairly adequate, first aid services are a requirement by law.

Health_consequences: SHORT-TERM: Skin burn, Carbon monoxide poisoning, systemic sepsis, multiorgan failure, fluid overload, pneumonia,kidney failure,,mortality,increase ambulance call-outs and slower response times. LONG-TERM: phychological stress, secondary pulmonary hypertension
Geographical_Area: 308 informal settlements are affected in Namibia. In 14 regions, affecting 35 health districts.
Exposure: Approximately,  17% (401 748/2.4 million) inhibitants lives in informal settlements affected by fire. Vulnerable groups are children, women, people living with dissabilities unemployed people and the elderly.
Vulnerability_Details: Lack of burn units/ burn treatment centres. Limited rescue and emergency  services, limited psycho-social support, congested and overcrowded settlements, poverty and unemployment, no alerting mechanism in the community, lack of kidney dialysis centres, lack of trained personnels at community level in terms of fire rescue and responders.
Governance_and_Resouces: Existence of casualty units trained real life trauma life supporters. Available of medical supplies. Treatment guidelines in existence. Availability of trained and equiped fire fighters at local authority. Existence of coordination mechanism with  enforcements agents. Available  early warning system and health emergency response teams. Awareness amongst the community members. National emergency toll free numbers.

Health_consequences: SHORT-TERM: Skin burn,  acute radiation syndromes, mortality, trauma,gastrointestinal syndrome.                      LONG-TERM:  cancer, reproductive, catalacts, disorders.
Geographical_Area: Medical-2 facilities in Windhoek, 1 facility in Swakopmund, 1 facility in Oshakati. Hospital staff, patients and population in the vicinity are at risk. Industrial -300 radioisotopes sources countrywide for industrial activities.
Exposure: Medical radioisotopes- 72 Health workers and 600 patients and 407 124 nearby communities (Oshakati 36 541, Windhoek 325 858, Swakopmund 44725). Total 407 751 persons.          Industrial radioisotopes-36 874 workers.               Approximately 18% (444 625 / 2 400 000) of population could be affected.
Vulnerability_Details: Lack of burn units. Fair access to health facilities with limited diagnostic capacity in radiation medical emergencies. Lack poisons and toxins management centre. Lack of  community knowledge on radiation and nuclear technology. High prevalence of co-morbidities within patients.  Inadequate capacity for Radiation Regulator (NRPA).
Governance_and_Resouces: Legislation in place for radiation for protection and emergency response. Established regulatory authorities in place. Some capacity in radiation and nuclear technology at medical facilities using radioisotopes (e.g. Radiation oncology therapists, nuclear physicians, nuclear physicists) and well trained radiation professionals in industry (Radiation safety officers). Radiation protection and safety SOPs in place and mplemented.

Health_consequences: SHORT-TERM: Skin burn, trauma, gastrointestinal syndrome, kidney failure, mortality. LONG-TERM: Pyschological disorder, chronic-respiratory diseases
Geographical_Area: Employees at Dundee Tsumeb smelter in Oshikoto. Sulphuric acid used for smelting of copper.
Exposure: 800 employees at Dundee Tsumeb smelter are likely to be exposed. Mostly male youth. Appproximately30% (390/1300) Transnamib employees.
Vulnerability_Details: Limited rescue and emergency  services, lack of access and evacuation services and community attitudes resulting in railway accidents. Lack of burn units. Limited psycho-social support, lack of burn treatment centres, lack of kidney dialysis centres, lack of trained community first aiders responders, limited knowledge and skills of community members on management of sulphuric acid. Limited oxygen equipment, supplies, and medical sundries at facility levels. Lack of SOP for handling sulpuric acid.
Governance_and_Resouces: Occupational Health and Safety regulation in place. Response capability of most facilities is fairly adequate. First Aid services readily available. Existence of casualty units   and trained real life trauma life support. Available of medical supplies. Treatment guidelines in existence.

Health_consequences: SHORT-TERM:  skin burn,Trauma,mortality, overload of facilities and services, diversion of resources.                      LONG-TERM: physchological stress,  and physical disabilities.
Geographical_Area: Nation wide in all 14 regions (national roads). The most affected towns are mainly  Windhoek, Otjiwarongo, Tsumeb, Otavi and Swakopmund.
Exposure: As from 01 January 2020  to 03 October 2021,  2198 accidents were reported nation wide of  which  3851 injuries/2.5 million with 367 fatalities, population at risk is mostly youth, age 15 to 45 years. As from January 2020  to September 2021  about  16 379 MVA cases were  admitted country wide.
Vulnerability_Details: Lack of trauma units at all state hospitals. Limited resources (critical care services - specialized staff, rescue, emergency services, lack of psycho-social support and  lack of evacuation mechanism), limited capacities and capabilities e.g. emergency critical care specialist. Lack of coordination between National RTA Authorities (RAF, MVAF) and MOHSS for accident surveilance.
Governance_and_Resouces: Existence of casualty units trained real life trauma life support. Available of medical supplies. Treatment guidelines in existence. Existence of coordination mechanism with  enforcements agents. Awareness amongst the community members. National emergency toll free numbers.

Health_consequences: SHORT-TERM: Gastrointestinal syndrome, , overload of facilities and services. LONG-TERM:  possible environmental pollution (soil and water)
Geographical_Area: Nation wide in all 14 regions mainly in the rural, informal settlements and some local authorities. Lodging facilities along the rivers in the Northern regions due to influx of tourist populations.
Exposure: Approximately, 48.96% (1.2 million/2.4 million) people lives in  rural areas, and  17% (401 748/2.4 million) inhibitants lives in informal settlements.Population residing in the informal settlements without well established sewerage systems. approximately 1595973 tourist visit Namibia yearly.
Vulnerability_Details: Developmental facilities in close proximity with rivers. No municipal services at remote developmental areas. Poor education, lack of awareness among the community/vulnerable group facing the risk/danger of contaminated water. Poverty and ignorance. Poor coordination between the line ministries (MOHSS, MET,MWARD,MURD,MAWF). Non -compliance to set standards, natural disasters (flood), fast paced urbanization. No oxidation ponds in the rural area set up.Outdated oxidation ponds and lack of treatment plants. Lack of punitive measures.
Governance_and_Resouces: Waste management guidelines available. Existence of Environmental Health Practioners to enforce the law. RCCE officers available for community sensitization. Technical expertise from line ministries (MOHSS, MET, MWARD,MAWF). Inclusive proper planning for waste management. Existence oxidation pond and treatment plant. Risk area known.

Health_consequences: Damage to and loss of essential life support services - water, food, shelter and staff; Traumatic injuries; Mortality Overload of facilities and services; Psychosocial stress, Forced displacement of population, Corpse management & Sanitation facilities disruption
Geographical_Area: 4 health districts Opuwo(Sesfontein), Khorixas(Kamanjab-Anker) Karasburg(Ariamsvlei) and Usakos (Karibib);  Rural areas; The highest magnitude recorded was 5.4, however given the frequency a magnitude of 6.9 is possible
Exposure: The population at Risk for earthquake: Karasburg =20686; Kamanjab=8279; Anker area=3381;Sesfontein =4490 and Karibib = 10219
Vulnerability_Details: Lack of search and rescue services;  Inaccessibility to treatment/trouma centres; and current structure not able to withstand such impact
Governance_and_Resouces: Basic primary health care available; inadequate rapid respond team for such impact; lack of multihazard plan; Availability of standard treatement guidelines

Health_consequences: Acute and Chronic manultrition and femine;psychosocial stress; Mortality, Morbidity such as scabies, diarhoea diseases & respiratory diseases
Geographical_Area: People in rural areas/population are more at risk of being severely affected.
Exposure: There are approximately 520 400 people in rural areas nationwide who are likely to be affected.
Vulnerability_Details: Low latrine coverage; Lack of WASH facilities; Lack of basic knowledge of management of dehydration
Governance_and_Resouces: Manultrition guidelines available; Health care workers trained in Integrated Management of Newborn and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI); Ready to use therapeutic food and read to use supplementary food available at health facilities, including micro-nutrients ; Standard treatment guidelines

Health_consequences: Short term: Morbidity due to infectious, water, food, and Vector-borne diseases; Drowning; Mortality; Disruption of Infrastructure & Essential services(power, water, transport, productivity)
Geographical_Area: Khomas (Windhoek), Hardap (Mariental) and Erongo (Walvis Bay)
Exposure: The total population at risk is 636 942
Vulnerability_Details: Inadequate sanitation facilities; lack of  information on floods` impacts; improper waste management system; Lack of swimming skills
Governance_and_Resouces: Surveillance system available to detect morbidities related to water, vector and food borne disease (indicators surveillance) however event based surveillance need to be strengthened; Emergency responders available; collaborations among different institutions on early warning; Standards treatment guidelines available

Health_consequences: Morbidity due to infectious and water, food, and Vector-borne diseases; Drowning; Mortality; Disruption of Infrastructure & Essential services(power, water, transport, productivity)
Geographical_Area: Possible affected areas include Walvis Bay, Swakopmund, Henties Bay and Luderitz
Exposure: The total population at risk is 196 497 people.
Vulnerability_Details: Lack of swimming skills among community and health care workers. Inadequate information on floods` impacts; lack of proper storm water drainage system;
Governance_and_Resouces: Surveillance system available to detect morbidities related to water, vector and food borne disease (indicators surveillance) however event based surveillance need to be strengthened; Emergency responders available; collaborations among different institutions;

Health_consequences: Immediate: Morbidity due to infectious and water, food, and Vector-borne diseases (Malaria; Drowning; Mortality; Disruption of Infrastructure & Essential services(power, water, transport, productivity)
Geographical_Area: River flooding affects mostly Zambezi (Zambezi - Chobe -Liyanti basin), Kavango West & East (Kavango - Epukiro basin), Omusati, Oshana and Ohangwena (Cuvelai - Etosha basin), Oshikoto region
Exposure: The total population at risk is 535 498
Vulnerability_Details: Inadequate indoor residual spraying (IRS) coverage; presence of vectors and breeding sites;lack of compliance to set standards on setlement (in tributaries & flood prone areas); low latrine coverage; lack of swimming skills
Governance_and_Resouces: Vector Control Programme available; Availability of outreach programme; surveillance system available to detect morbidities related to water, vector and food borne disease (indicators base surveillance); Emergency responders available; collaborations among different institutions; Early waning sytem available; Standard treatment guidelines available

Health_consequences: Morbidity (Cold, Flu due to seasonal or pandemic influenza, Sore throats, Norovirus, Heart Attacks, Hypothermia, and Frost bite, Immersion foot / trench foot),
Geographical_Area: Southern regions -(Hardap & //Karas). People living in improvised housesing units are more at risk.
Exposure: 74 033 people in the two regions are at high risk, these are vulnerable people who lives in imrpvised housing units. (Hardap 51 280 and 22 753 in ||Kharas region) representing  52.8%  in Hardap and 25.2% in ||Kharas region.
Vulnerability_Details: over-crowding leading to unhygienic conditions; Lack of awareness on immune booster suppliments; vulnerable community with no proper shelter;
Governance_and_Resouces: Presence of primary health care services; Standard treatment guidelines available; Indicator based surveillance system available; Active referral health system

Health_consequences: Traumatic injuries(Mainly burning), psychosocial stress, Mortality, physical disability, Damage to and loss of essential life support services - Water, food, shelter
Geographical_Area: Mass wild fires affecting Ohangwena, Kunene, Khomas, Otjozondjupa and Oshikoto regions. Mostly rural areas and national parks
Vulnerability_Details: Proximity to health facilities; Limited treatment for people with serious burning wounds; Lack of psychosocial first aid; Limited of medical capacity to response to adverse fire casualties
Governance_and_Resouces: Basic medical supplies to treat fire wounds available at health facilities; emergency referral system in place; availability of standard treatment guidelines

Health_consequences:
Immédiates(Morbidité: élevé: 124234 cas en 2022) Létalité élévée (1965 decés), augmentation de la demande des services de santé  mentale et soutien psychologique 
Sécondaires:séquelles importantes pulmonaires,  Pertubation des services de santé essentielles,stress post traumatique, psychose et stigmatisation
Geographical_Area: Tout le pays (Adamaoua, Cente, Est, Extrême-nord, Littoral, Nord, Nord-Ouest, Ouest,  Sud, Sud-Ouest)
Exposure: Personnes âgées ( 60+) 1 255 508 Personnes avec comorbidités (2 475 000), Femmes enceinte(1 400 000)= 5 130 508
Vulnerability_Details: Facteurs de vulnerabilité communautaire: Taux croissant des Maladies Chroniques Non Transmissibles; Prelavalence élévée du VIH (2,7%) ; faible revenue; augmentation du chômage;  relachement des mésures barrières  Vulnerabilité du système de santé : Plateau technique insuffisant ; ressources humaines et financères  insufisantes; abscence de l'assurance santé; insuffisance des programmes de CREC ; couverture vaccinale faible (22%), relachement des activités de surveillance et de reponse,faible coordination transfrontalière entre les pays; abscence d'une ligne budgetaire avec des mecanises de decaissements claire pour la gestion des urgences,
Governance_and_Resouces: Evaluation externe conjointe ( JEE) faite en 2017, PANSS élaboré et en cours de mise en eouvre, SIMEX fonctionnelle en 2022, RIA faite en 2022, Existence des Plans (plan préparation et réponse, plan de riposte et de relèvement du système de santé; plan d'action de l'incident. Plan de résurgence) CCOUPS en place, SGI COVID19 activé; coordination multisectorielle activé; SIMR disponible et fonctionnelle;  forte implication des Partenaires Technique et financier et sociétés civiles impliquées dans la riposte; Publication des articles scientifiques disséminant les stratégies de ropostes contre la COVID19 ; tenue fréquente des réunions de coordinations et de ripostes ; disponibilité des fonds;
Health_Sector_Capacity: surveillance effective à tous les niveau de la pyramide sanitaire; Depistage systématique du voyageurs au psf et aéroportuaire; intégration du point COVID dans les réunions hebdomadaire du niveau central avec les régions ; formations de 100 cliniciens au régional à la prise en charge des cas sévères; Capacité de prise en charge renforcée, Formalisation et viabilisation dU réseau national des laboratoire COVID19; 10 centres hosptaliers dans les 10 regions, Renforcement du réseau national des laboratoires; renforcement des capacités du personnel santé
Non_Health_Sector_Capcity: Gestion effective des rumeurs à travers les centres d'appel; intensification de la communication publique  (conférences de presse, medias radio télé etc,,,)la communication gourvenementale;
Commuty_Capacity: Surveillance basée sur les évênements; Formation des   acteurs communautaires sur la surveillance à base communautaire; impliquation des acteurs communautaire dans les enquêtes socio-anthropologique

Health_consequences: Immédiates: morbidité élevée: 3473 cas suspects investigués et 2532 cas confirmés par la biologie en 2022, Mortalité infantile élevée, propagation rapideSécondaire: Démence; infections respiratoires sévères
Geographical_Area: Tout le pays (Adamaoua, Cente, Est, Extrême-nord, Littoral, Nord, Nord-Ouest, Ouest,  Sud, Sud-Ouest)
Exposure: Enfants de 0 à 5 ans  non vaccinés = 1 000 000
Vulnerability_Details: Facteurs de vulnerabilité communautaire: population agée de moins de 5 ans; malnutrition; faible immunité de la population cible (76,1%  pour la 1ère dose et 44,8% pour la deuxième dose); Flembée épidemique des pays frontaliés   Vulnerabilité du système de santé accès limités aux services de santé (40%); irrégularité des campagnes de riposte; seul 70% des FOSA offrent les services de Vaccination, Insuffisance de formation des personnels de santé sur la surveillance des MEV; faible communication du personnel de santé sur la deuxieme dose,abscence d'une ligne budgetaire avec des mecanises de decaissements claire pour la gestion des urgences

Health_Sector_Capacity: la valence rubéole introduit dans le vaccin contre la rougeole en 2019; administration du Vaccin en deux doses (RR1; RR2);  Prise en charge des cas de rougeole , taux de letalité 5,6% pour 100 000 Habitant; SEF en place et fonctionnelle;
Non_Health_Sector_Capcity: Communication en millieu scolaire,
Commuty_Capacity: existence des relais communaitres;

Governance_and_Resouces: existence plan d'action de l'incident, SGI activé, évaluation externe conjointe (JEE) faite en 2017, plan d'action national de sécurité s ressources humaine, logistiques et financières mobilisées, collaboration multisectorielle, renforcement décentralisé des capacités, réalisation d'enquêtes et CREC faits, implication multisectorielle de haut niveau.PANSS élaboré et en cours de mise en eouvre, SIMR disponible et fonctionnelle;

Health_consequences: Immédiates:flambées épidémiques, morbidité: 38 cas confirmés par séro neutralisation ou PCR, 1766 cas suspects investigués, Mortalité infantile élevée, propagation rapideSécondaire:

Health_consequences: Immédiates: flambées épidémiques, morbidité: 1473 cas suspects investigués en 2022, létalité élévée (49 décès en 2022), Sécondaires: importantes séquelles(séquelles neurologique, pertes auditives, faibleese des membres, troubles vision parole, mémoire et language), amputation des membres

Exposure: Personnes vivantes dans les régions appartenant à la ceinture méningique, Personne immuno dépriméé: 13 308 185
Vulnerability_Details: population à risque enfants de - de 5ans , Régions dans la ceinture méningique (extrême nord, nord, adamaoua, est et nord ouest) vaccins non intégré au PEV de routine, faible revenu des ménages, assurance maladie insuffisante , vaccin recommandé rare et inacessible, coût élévé du vaccin, laboratoire de référence éloignés des zones à risque, plusieurs pays voisins en épidémie; abscence d'une ligne budgetaire avec des mecanises de decaissements claire pour la gestion des urgences

Geographical_Area: Tout le pays (Adamaoua, Cente, Est, Extrême-nord, Littoral, Nord, Nord-Ouest, Ouest,  Sud, Sud-Ouest)
Exposure: 1/6 Population éxposée = 4 666 666  Personnes
Vulnerability_Details: absence d'un centre national anti poison, absence d'un sytème fiable de collecte des données, réseau INFOSAN pas très opérationel, manque de SOP de surveillance des intoxications, la collecte et le traitement des données, faibles mécanismes de contrôle des produits alimentaires, abscence d'une ligne budgetaire avec des mecanises de decaissements claire pour la gestion des urgences

Health_consequences: Conséquences immédiates:  Détresse respiratoire, décès ,  choc septique, pneumonie grave, propagation rapide pouvant entrainer une pandémie. Conséquences secondaires:  pneumonie chronique, troubles psychologiques, perturbation des services de santé, mutations virales, pertes socio-économiques avec mauvaise qualité des soins et baisse de la fréquentation des hopitaux.
Geographical_Area: Centre, Ouest, Sud, Adamaoua, Extreme-Nord, Nord
Exposure: Acteurs de la chaine de valeur avicole (fermiers, transporteurs, commercants, plumeurs, captureurs, consommateurs, restaurateurs…). Rajouter les informations socio-démographiques (sexe, age... les plus à risque)
Vulnerability_Details: Le Cameroun est un hot spot pour l'émergence des maladies zoonotiques, insuffisance de formation des fermiers sur la biosécurité, personnel de santé pas suffisamment formé sur la prise en charge des cas humains, insuffisance des fonds pour la gestion des cas, lenteurs dans le décaissement des fonds, la mauvaise gestion des déchets d'élevage
Governance_and_Resouces: Existence du Programme National de Prévention et de Lutte contre les Zoonoses Emergentes et Réémergentes (PNPLZER), Existence de la Stratégie Nationale "Une Santé", existence du CCOUSP. Elaboration des plans de lutte et POS, existence d'un cadre juridique favorable, existence du point focal national RSI (2005), existence du plan multirisque, personnel formé à la gestion des cas, existence d'un fond dédié à la gestion des épidémies, réalisation des exercices de simulation grandeur nature et sur table, existence du plan national multirisque, appui des partenaires techniques et financiers pour la mise en oeuvre des activités,
Health_Sector_Capacity: existence des formations sanitaires à tous les niveaux, disponibilité des laboratoires de diagnostic, existence d'un plateau technique, formation/renforcement des capacités des personnels de santé à la prise en charge des cas
Non_Health_Sector_Capcity: L'existence d'une filière avicole organisée; existence des marchés de volailles ou est régulièrement pratiquée l'inspection sanitaire vétérinaire; le MINEPIA est en charge de la surveillance des fermes et marchés de volailles; le MINFOF assure le suivi des oiseaux migrateurs à travers les écogardes, formation/renforcement en continu des capacités des personnels vétérinaires et de la faune; le cadre réglementaire favorise la prise de décision à plusieurs niveaux; en cas d'épizootie, les FMO arrurent la sécurité des acteurs de terrain;
Commuty_Capacity: Existence de la surveillance fondée sur les événements (SFE/SBC);

Commuty_Capacity: Existence de la surveillance fondée sur les événements (SFE/SBC); Immunisation d'une partie de la population (+50ans) contre la variole humaine.

Health_consequences: Conséquences immédiates: propagation rapide pouvant entrainer une pandémie, interruption de la circulation des biens et des personnes, forte contagiosité, décès, avortements. Conséquences secondaires: stigmatisation, perturbation des services de santé, destruction du tissu social, pertes socio-économiques avec augmentation de la malnutrition, famine, baisse du taux de fréquentation des hopitaux et aggravation des maladies chroniques pouvant conduire à la mort.

Exposure: 27744989. La population n'est pas immunisée et la contagiosité élevée
